Dear Sir:

Re: Buildings 28, 38 and 18, Macleod, Alta.

We have your letter of January 21st in which you refer to buildings at Pearce and Macleod, Alta.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Classroom Blocks, for Blood Residential School
and St. Paul's Residential School.

There are two residential schools situated on the
Blood Reserve, namely the Blood (Roman Catholic) School, with a
pupillage of 150, and the St. Paul's (Anglican) School, with
a pupillage of 140.

Indian Superintendent Regan, along with the Principals
of these Schools, has made an extensive survey of buildings of the
R.C.A.F. camps in the area of Cardston, Alberta, and has located
two ideal buildings to fill the educational needs of his reserve.
These buildings are as described below:

1. Building No. 36, R.C.A.F. Station, Macleod, Alberta.

This building is needed at the Blood R.C. Residential
School as an additional classroom building. It is a former
Link Trainer building. It is of frame construction, in very
good condition, with storm windows and completely shingled
on the outside. The inside contains four good-sized class-
rooms, each 25' x 36', a large cloakroom for each classroom,
a Principal's office and very adequate washrooms and furnace-
room. The ceiling is finished in Tuf-Tect, the walls are
lined with 3-ply veneer in very good condition, and the
whole building is floored with tempered masonite. All
plumbing and electrical fixtures, as well as all heating
apparatus are still intact. This building was used as
classrooms during the war and is ideal for the need on the Blood Reserve. It can be moved without dismantling; it is built in the form of an H, with two classrooms on either side and would be moved in three pieces very easily.

2. Building No. 12, R.C.A.F., Station, Fearce, Alberta.

This building is needed for additional classroom space at the St. Paul's Residential School on the Blood Reserve. It is similar in every way to the Link Trainer building at Macleod, only this building has four classrooms, each size 15 x 24, and all on one side of the building. This building is 76 feet long and 30 feet wide and complete with electrical wiring (although the fixtures are gone) plumbing and heating. There are four classrooms, two offices, large washroom and heating room. It is ideal for the purpose intended and could be moved intact.

The Director of the Lands and Buildings Department of War Assets Corporation advises that these buildings are available at the following prices:

(a) Building No. 38 ..... $1,358.60
(b) Building No. 12 ..... $1,160.51

Both the above prices represent 5% of the cost of construction. From our past experience with converting such buildings for school use, we immediately requested Inspector Godberham to advise us as to the maximum cost of moving these buildings. We have now received an army signal from him, reading as follows:

"METEL AIRFORCE BLDGE NEAR BLOOD RESERVE - stop -
MAXIMUM COST MOVING #12 PEARCE $1800 and #38 MacLEOD $2800 -
stop- HAGAN ESTIMATES TOTAL COST INCLUDING PURCHASE AT NEW LOCATIONS $5000.00 FOR PEARCE BLDG. AND $6000.00 for MACLEOD".

These two buildings will provide classroom accommodation for 150 children in each instance. It will mean that we can offer full day tuition for the children at each of these two schools and will also enable us to increase the pupilage. It
should be possible to convert one or more of the present classrooms in these schools to additional dormitory use.

Both these schools are some 30 miles to the south and a river lies between them and the airport sites. It will be necessary to move these buildings in the near future so as to take advantage of the ice now covering the river.

In a recent letter Superintendent Hagan advised this branch: "As you know, this reserve has over 200 children who cannot be educated for lack of accommodation; we have the staff, the land and everything but the buildings." Therefore, it is recommended that you consider the inclusion of a sum of $12,000.00 in the Supplementary Estimates for the cost, moving and setting up of these two classroom blocks for the two residential schools as mentioned above. It is estimated that the construction of new classroom blocks at these two residential schools would cost $40,000.00 for each building, or a total of $80,000.00 in all.

[Signature]

Director

Dear Mr. Neary:

Your letter file 103-2-5-(E) of the 9th instant has been received, and I want to thank you for same.

On my return from Ottawa I got in touch with Mr. O. O. Davis, War Assets, Calgary, regarding Building No. 18. I also saw him yesterday in Calgary and here is what he had to say.

Building No. 18 has not been released as yet, but should be released with the next group of buildings in the very near future. This Recreation Centre at one time was requested and used by the army, but lately has been abandoned because it was too big. Lately also the heating equipment has been taken out of the building.

I will be going to Macleod within a day or two and see if some of the released buildings could be used to advantage. My plans call for cinder block construction and a steel truss. The latter is being made in my shop at the present time. The cinder blocks can be bought locally. The lumber from the gym or other building could be used for the roof, main floors and inside finish.

I am very anxious to get on with my plans early in the spring, and if you could supply me with the following materials, I could go right ahead.

500 sacks cement $1800.00
9000 concrete blocks @ 20¢ each
10,000 ft. 2x8x18 @ $48.00 per mill
8000 ft. 2x12x18 @ $48.00 per mill
18,000 ft. rough lumber @$48.00 per thousand.
I understand that this is a considerable amount of material, but I do not think it could cost more than the purchase price of Recreational Hall No. 18. This material is all new and has the additional advantage that I would not have to spend a considerable amount of money and time to take the building apart.

To begin with I would require the cement and the blocks. At the present time construction is at a standstill and cement and blocks are available. But in a month's time it would be very scarce. As for the lumber all I would have to do for the present time is to notify the Indian mill at Brocket of my requirements. It would then be available in May or June. In the meantime, if the gym becomes available, we could cancel the lumber contract, or sell it at a profit.

Hoping that I will hear from you soon, I am,

Yours very sincerely,

Rev. P.A. Charron, S.M.

Rev. P. A. Charron, O.M.I.

Re: Classroom Blocks, Blood and St. Paul's Residential Schools, Blood Reserve.

Further to correspondence on the above buildings, and proposed purchase from War Assets Corporation - your file 103-2-5 (E), we submit herewith written tender for the moving of Bldg. No. 12 at Pearce and No. 38 at Macleod.

It will be impossible to have this moving done in the present fiscal year and it is anticipated that it will take a good part of the coming summer. The contractors much prefer to move these buildings through the water of the river, rather than over the ice, and they now have moving commitments to keep them busy until late Spring; it will also be much more satisfactory to complete cement foundations after danger of frost.

Ottawa, February 24, 1948.

Mr. G.H. Gooderham, Regional Supervisor, Calgary, Alta.,

Classroom Block, Blood and St. Paul's Residential Schools, Blood Reserve.

The necessary requisitions have been forwarded to the Departmental Purchasing Agent for the purchase of building No. 12 at Pearce, Alberta and building No. 38 at Macleod, Alberta. It is presumed that the Calgary office of the War Assets Corporation will be advising you shortly as to the date upon which these buildings can be taken over.

We have also received Superintendent Hagan's letter of February 20th with attached tender from North Lethbridge Motors Limited for the moving of the buildings.

Before this tender is submitted to the Minister's office for the necessary approval, could we please be advised as to whether the tender includes the placing of the foundations or whether it is expected that we will provide the necessary cement foundations before these buildings are moved.

It is also felt that interior changes will have to be made to these buildings and that the windows will have to be moved to provide maximum fenestration. In view of the fact that these buildings can not be moved until the summer, it is felt that these alterations can be the subject of future correspondence. Would you suggest that an Engineer from the Lands and Development Services be consulted with regard to these alterations.

Bernard P. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Re: Classroom Block St. Paul's Residential School, Blood Reserve.

Your files 103-2-5 and 103-1-5 (E).

Upon receipt of yours of the 24th instant, I contacted the Manager of the War Assets Corporation, Calgary, and learned that his office had just received a directive to say that Building #12 at Pearce and Building #38 at Macleod have been allocated to the Indian Affairs Branch, and would be released when notification of payment for them had been received.

I have not yet contacted Superintendent Ragan, but I know that the tenders do not include the placing of the foundations. This work must be done either by day labor or by contract when weather conditions allow. I would not recommend that such work be done until the weather at least is fine and warm, and that will be in the new fiscal year. It is not at all likely that the mover will get the buildings on to the reserve before early summer.

In the meantime, the foundations can be made. (I have moved numerous buildings and set them up in the air until the foundations were laid. This is not the best procedure, of course.)

In regard to the changes to be made to these buildings, I cannot remember how the windows are placed, but I would not attempt to do any alterations until they are on the new foundations. Will not fenestration be subject to the direction the front is facing, and whether or not they are clear of other large buildings? I also consider it too early to consult with an Engineer from the Lands & Development Service.

I am asking Mr. Ragan to locate the sites for these buildings and to obtain some figures on cost of foundations, to be submitted to you.

Dear Father Charbon:

I have for answer your letter of February 13 and I have delayed in answering you until we were certain about the purchase of the two classroom block buildings. This has now been settled and the necessary purchase orders have been issued. It would seem from your letter that building No. 15 is still somewhat in doubt and that you are now proposing to erect your own gymnasium building. You are therefore requesting that the Department provide you with the building materials for this construction rather than purchasing recreation hall No. 15. Your request would involve the following approximate expenditures:

- Cement: $500.00
- Concrete blocks: $1,800.00
- Lumber, approximately: $1,800.00

Total: $4,100.00

In the first place, we simply have not the funds available for this expenditure. This is now the last month of the fiscal year and we are already committed to the fullest extent. Therefore, we can do nothing during this month at least, with regard to your proposal.

In the second place, I feel that the above expenditure would be considerably more than the purchase price of recreation hall No. 15. Of course I cannot confirm this point because the building has not yet been declared surplus.

In the third place, there is no mention made in your letter of the labour involved in the construction of this building. However, I do not want to drop this proposal but wish that you would thoroughly discuss it with Mr. Gooderham when the
opportunity presents itself. I am sending him a copy of this letter and am also forwarding one to Father Flourde. I will expect to hear further from you, clarifying this situation and advising me of any further developments.

Yours sincerely,

Bernard F. Neary,

Re: Blood Residential School Gymnasium.

Further to our recent conversation with Rev. Father P.A. Charron of the Blood R.C. Residential School of this Reserve regarding the building of a gymnasium for that school, we now forward you complete plans of the proposed building.

The plans, I believe, are self explanatory; Father Charron now has the trusses all complete for the building, these are of steel and very well constructed. The Principal also has on hand sufficient steel-framed windows for this building and wrought iron for reinforcing the concrete. I might add that Father Charron has had considerable experience in construction work of various kinds and I have seen very creditable buildings which he has built. He now has the staff at the school and is prepared to go ahead with the construction of this gym, but is rightfully asking that the Department contribute to the build-

Mr. Neary's letter 103-2-5 (E) of March 26th, 1948, in which I believe was forwarded your recommendation, completely the idea of purchasing an existing gym for this school - firstly because it is not yet available and secondly because we find that it would cost more to dismantle and move this building than it would cost for the construction of the building as designed by Father Charron. Other than that the proposed building will be semi-fireproof while Building No. 18 would be a fire trap.

Father Charron has asked that the following materials be supplied by the Department:

| Material       | Cost   |
|----------------|--------|
| Cement         | $500.00|
| Concrete blocks| $1800.00|
| Lumber         | $1800.00|
|                | $4100.00|
The concrete blocks are manufactured in Cardston and the lumber will be secured from the Peigan Indian Mill at Brocket. All labour will be undertaken by Father Charron and his Staff and cost of all steel trusses, etc. will be borne by the Principal.

There is no question of the need of a building of this type at this - or any - school. During the last winter I have seen Indian children "scooped" into small recreation rooms, with little or no facilities for play, which has more forcibly brought the need of a building of this type to my mind.

As will be noticed from the plans, it is intended to have a large gym floor, with stage with bowling and manual training rooms and dormitories on either side. It is the idea of the Principal to house the large boys in the dormitory in this building, separating them from the smaller boys and thereby eliminating the cause for much complaint among parents; at the same time of course, this would allow for a greater pupilage providing the classroom blocks are available.

It will also be noticed that a room has been set aside for a museum; Father Charron has one of the most complete collections of Indian relics and handicraft in this part of the country and it is my opinion that these should be displayed in a museum of some kind in order that they may be preserved and viewed by the public. I feel that the Blood Reserve is fortunate in having a collection such as Father Charron's.

It is certainly my recommendation that the $4,100.00 be allowed toward the cost of construction of this most useful and necessary building. It is hoped that authority can be obtained for the sum. I might add that Father Charron has given much thought and effort - as well as dollars - to this project and I believe his efforts should be

Lethbridge, Alberta.

June 12th, 1948.

The Honourable James A. MacKinnon,
Minister of Mines and Resources,
OTTAWA, Ontario.

Dear Mr. MacKinnon:

The people of Alberta, I am sure, will be very pleased to hear that you have accepted the heavy responsibility of becoming Minister of Mines and Resources, and I hasten to wish you every success in your new Department.

I believe that this Department should always be in charge of a Western man and if possible a man from Alberta. The future of Edmonton is bound up with the development of the mining and other resources of the North West Territories; the three main National Parks are in Alberta, and the largest Indian Reserves are in this Province.

Just so that you will have a problem to deal with immediately, I am writing to you with reference to the following matter.

Recently I had a visit from Rev. Father Charron of the Blood Indian R.C. Residential School and he requested me to give him any assistance I could on the following matter.

Father Charron at the present time is building a gymnasium which is to be used by the Indian children attending this school. He has asked the Department of Indian Affairs for financial assistance to the amount of $4,100.00. He was very hopeful that his request would be granted but it now has been turned down.

I enclose copies of the correspondence which will give you the complete story. You will note that Mr. Ragan, the local Indian Agent wholeheartedly supports the request.
In support of the request Father Charron pointed out that through his personal operation of the farm attached to the school he has put in over $25,000.00 in each of the past two years towards maintaining the school apart from the Government grant of $218.00 per pupil per year paid on the basis of 175 pupils last year.

You will note that moving the buildings from Macleod to the school will increase the classroom and teaching space but it will accentuate the need for recreational space.

At the moment there is one recreation room for boys and one for girls, each 40 x 50 with 8 foot ceilings and steel posts every nine feet. The sanitary facilities for each room are contained in small rooms and have no ventilation. With the posts there is no chance for indoor sports or games and the rooms when used are badly overcrowded.

There is a crying need for a gymnasium at this school. Due to our Chinook winds the winters are broken and it is impossible to carry on an outdoor schedule of skating, hockey, etc. The school has no place for plays or visual training.

As you know there has been strong criticism in the past of the conduct of Indian Schools. However, I believe that St. Mary's School on the Blood Reserve enjoys an excellent reputation and is worthy of some recognition.

The situation on the Blood Reserve according to Father Charron is that there are 195 pupils at his school, 140 at St. Paul's Anglican School and somewhere near 200 Indian children are running wild on the reserve and not attending school at all. He says that the population on this Reserve has increased from 1100 in 1931 to 1800 at present and the birth rate at present is 47 per 1000.

If this small amount of $4100.00 can be inserted in the supplementary estimates I am sure that it will serve a very useful purpose and will gladden the lives of 195 Indian children who at the best do not enjoy a very full life.

With very best wishes,

Yours sincerely,

L.S. TURCOTTE

per M. Turcotte.

Dear Mr. Turcotte:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of June 12 concerning the gymnasium for the Blood Residential School. When Father Charron visited the Indian Affairs Branch last winter, he requested that consideration be given to the purchase of building No. 18 at the Macleod R.C.A.F. station. You will note in Father Plourde's letter of January 20 that he makes the following statement:

We then wrote to the War Assets Corporation concerning this building and were advised that it had not yet been declared surplus. The cost of this building would probably have been between $1,000 and $1,500.

We were then advised that the idea of purchasing building No. 18 as a gymnasium for the school had been abandoned completely. It was on this occasion that we were advised that $4,100.00 would be required for the construction of the gymnasium.

In the meantime we had included in our supplementary estimates an amount of $12,000 for the moving and conversion of two other R.C.A.F. buildings at Pearce and Macleod for use as classroom blocks at the Blood and St. Paul's Residential Schools. Father Charron was therefore advised that if any surplus was available from this $12,000 it would be devoted to the erection of his gymnasium.

However, the moving and conversion of these two classroom blocks will now evidently take more than the $12,000 allotted.
It will probably be necessary to transfer funds from other projects in order to have these classroom blocks completed by September first. It is felt that the erection of these classroom blocks with full basements is a more important project than the erection of a gymnasium. It is difficult at the present time to decide whether it will be possible to transfer additional funds that might be devoted to the erection of this building. However, officials of the Department are in sympathy with the requirements of the Blood School and consideration will be given to the requirements there if and when funds are available.

Yours sincerely,

Relative to the above, on this date at 10:45 AM, a telephone call was received at this detachment from the St. Mary's School on the Blood Indian Reserve to the effect that a workman had been electrocuted while working on the new gymnasium, which is being built in connection with the school. It was learned that Dr. Jno. A. KEY had already been notified and was at the scene of the accident.

2. Sgt. H. D. Ferguson and the writer immediately patrolled to the Indian School. Upon arriving there it was ascertained that Merlin HALL of Cardston, Alta., had been working directly under some high tension wires and a long iron rod which he was handling had come in contact with one of the wires. Artificial Respiration had been applied, but upon arrival of Dr. KEY, HALL was pronounced dead.

3. The following observations and measurements were made at the scene of the accident. The gymnasium on which HALL was employed is located on the north side of the main school building. The walls are being constructed of cinder blocks and have been completed. The power line which HALL came in contact with runs east and west lengthwise over the gymnasium. This power line leads from the line running along the road in front of the school to the back of the school where it enters the building. This line which leads from the main line carries 18,000 volts as the bank of transformers are located at the back of school. In other words the voltage is not reduced until just before it enters the school buildings.

4. On the inside walls of the gymnasium a scaffold has been erected. At the time of the accident HALL was employed on the scaffolding on the east wall. He was placing long iron rods in a form that had been built on top of the cinder brick wall. These rods were to be used in reinforcing the cement, which was to be placed in these forms. Just previous to the accident, Billy HEAVY RUNNER and Indian had handed about a dozen of these rods up to HALL and HALL had laid them on the scaffold. The rods which had been handed up had been laid directly under the power line. Apparently HALL had placed one of the rods in the forms and then reached down and picked another one up. The second one he was about to place in the form was no doubt the rod that touched the wire. It was also possible that HALL was standing on the other rods. There were two other workmen working on the scaffold nearby when the accident happened.

5. The east wall of the gymnasium is 60' 6" in length and is 80' 6" in height, that is to say the top of the forms.
The scaffold is 4' 9" below the top of the form. There are three wires passing from east to west over this wall. The centre wire is 16' from the south wall. The north wire is 18' above the top of the form. The centre wire is the highest and is 4' 3". The south wire is 2' 1" above the form. The wire which HALL touched with the rod was the north wire which is only 6' 3" above the scaffolding. The rod which HALL was placing in the form was 15' 1/2" in length. There was a burnt mark on this rod 4' from one end, no doubt being where it came in contact with the power line.

6. Dr. Jas. A. KEY, local Coroner and the writer examined the body. No burn marks could be found other than a slight burn on the rubber sole of the right shoe which HALL was wearing. On this shoe there was a slight burn around two nails in the sole. The body was removed to HALL'S funeral home in Cardston. HALL'S watch and .15¢ in cash were turned over to Vern HALL, brother of the deceased.

7. After viewing the scene, Dr. Jas. A. KEY local Coroner ordered that an Inquest be held. Dr. KEY issued a warrant to take possession of the body and to summon a Jury. The following jurors were summoned, Warren SMITH, Garage Prop., Cardston, Alta.; William SLOAN, Merchant, Cardston, Alta.; Orson ANDERSON, Farmer, Cardston, Alta.; Jerry McIntyre, Merchant, Cardston, Alta.; William LADLAN, Merchant, Cardston, Alta.; Elmo NELSON, Farmer, Cardston, Alta., to appear at the Court House, Cardston, Alta., at 2:30 pm. on this date. The Jury picked Warren SMITH as Foreman. The body was viewed at HALL'S funeral home, Cardston and then the scene of the accident was viewed. The jury then adjourned until 2:00 pm. on the 26-6-48.

8. The following is a statement obtained from Gilbert L. SCHAFER, Cardston, Alta., a carpenter that was employed on the scaffold with HALL.

Cardston, Alta.,
June 25th, 1948.

Statement of Gilbert L. SCHAFER.

At about 10:00 am. this morning I was working on the new recreation hall at the Roman Catholic School on the Blood Reserve. I was up on the scaffold, working on the north east corner. I was with Tony MILK building form. I heard Merlin HALL suddenly shout and when I turned around he had hold of a rod, this rod was touching the wires of the power line above the structure, sparks were flying between the rod that he held and the wires. Almost immediately he collapsed on the scaffolding, his head was hanging over the edge and I pulled him back and commenced to administer artificial respiration. At this point Father CHARON came up and we moved Merlin off the bars on to a flatter spot. We continued to apply artificial respiration until Mr. CODY arrived and he took over for a few minutes. At this point Dr. KEY arrived and pronounced him dead. The Dr. arrived at about 10:35 am. I heard Father CHARON warn Merlin HALL to be careful of the wires while putting the rods in place.

Witnessed, Capt. H. D. Ferguson

(Signed) G. L. Schaffer.
9. The following is a statement obtained from Antoni WILK, who is a Polish Refugee employed by St. Mary's Roman Catholic School on the Blood Indian Reserve. WILK was also on the scaffold when HALL met his death.

Cardston, Alta.,
June 25th, 1948.

Statement of Antoni WILK.

At about 10:00 am., shortly after I was working with Gilbert SCHAFER on the new recreation hall at the Roman Catholic School on the Blood Indian Reserve. I heard someone make a noise and turned around and saw Merlin HALL swaying with one of the metal bars in his hands. The bar was apparently touching the wire of the power line which was above the structure. There seemed to be smoke rising from either the bar or the wire. Almost immediately HALL fell to the scaffolding. I ran to get Father CHARON, we both came back and Father CHARON instructed an Indian to go and tell Mr. GODY. While waiting for the doctor to arrive I assisted Gilbert SCHAFER in giving HALL artificial respiration. The doctor arrived about 10:30 am. and pronounced HALL dead.

I heard Father CHARON warn everyone to be careful of the wires. He had done this often and even wrote a warning on a board under the wires. This board had been removed at the time of the accident.

Witnessed, Cst. H. D. Ferguson. (signed) Antoni Wilk.

10. The following is a statement from Billy HEAVY RUNNER, an Indian who handed the iron rods up to HALL and who was on the ground when HALL touched the power line.

Cardston, Alta.
June 25th, 1948.

Statement of BILLY HEAVY RUNNER (Indian)

On June 25th I was working on the new recreation hall at the Roman Catholic School on the Blood Indian Reserve. I had been helping Merlin HALL, having just handed about 10 to 12 metal rods up to him. I turned my back and was talking to some people outside the structure. I heard someone make a noise and turning around saw Merlin HALL fall to the platform of the scaffolding on which he had been standing. He did not have anything in his hands when I looked around and he was almost right down on the platform. He landed with his head over the edge of the platform and I thought that he was in danger of falling off. I shouted to Tony WILK who was up on the scaffold to pull him back and he did this. I noticed that Merlin HALL was shaking when he was lying on the platform. I would estimate the time to be about 10:00 am. Dr. KEY was called and arrived about 25 minutes to 11:00 am. He inspected the body and pronounced him dead.

I had heard Father CHARON warn everybody to be careful of the wires which were overhead and everyone seemed to be aware of the fact that they were dangerous.

Witnessed, Cst. H. D. Ferguson. (signed) Billy H. Runner.

11. The following is a statement obtained from Father CHARON, who is in charge of the St. Mary's Roman Catholic School on the Blood Indian Reserve and also has charge of the construct...
Cardston, Alta.,
June 26th, 1948.

Statement of Paul Andrew CHARRON (Priest)

Yesterday morning I worked with the boys on the scaffolding placing forms on top of the walls, these forms were to be filled with cement at a later date. Before leaving I warned Merlin HALL and the others to be careful as there was great danger near the wires, they acknowledged this warning. I then departed to the school, shortly after a knock came at my door, and I was informed that there had been an accident. I immediately went to the building, looked up and saw Mr. SCHAFER. He seemed to be giving artificial respiration. He was up on the scaffold and I got up also and helped him. I had someone go and phone for the Doctor. We continued to give artificial respiration and Merlin seemed to be responding, sometimes to words and if not to signs which I made. When the Doctor arrived he informed us that it was useless to continue. I immediately left and notified the R. C. M. Police by telephone. I would estimate the time to be about 5 passed ten when I was first called to the scene of the accident.

Witnessed Cst. H. D. Ferguson. (Signed) Rev. P. A. Charron

There were numerous other persons around the gymnasium at the time of the accident. However, none of these persons actually saw it happen.

The following witnesses were summoned to appear for the Inquest at 2:00 pm. on June 26th, 1948. Gilbert SCHAFER, Antoni WILE, Father P. A. CHARRON and Billy HEAVY RUNNER.

On this date at 2:00 pm. the inquest was continued at the Court House, Cardston, Alta. All of the jurors were present along with the witnesses mentioned in para. 13. The evidence of the four witnesses followed the lines of the statements embodied in this report. The writer gave evidence in regard to the measurements etc. Father P. A. CHARRON in his evidence stated that he had requested the Calgary Power Co. to move the line over the Gymnasium about one month and a half ago. The poles had been put in for the new line, but no other work had been done. Father CHARRON had also requested the Power Co. to place the transformers on the road so the high voltage would not pass over the School grounds.

The Calgary Power Co. was represented at the Inquest by E. F. STRINGAM, local barrister and other officials of the Company.

The jury deliberated for one half hour and Warren SMITH, foreman of the jury brought in the following verdict.

"That at approximately 10:00 am. on June 25th, 1948 at St. Mary's R. C. School on the Blood Reserve, Cardston, while working on the new Recreational Hall now under construction, the said Merlin HALL came to his death."
accidentally by electrocution, by a rod he carried coming in contact with a live high tension wire which passed about eighteen inches above the wall he was working on.

17. From the investigation and the evidence at the inquest there is no doubt that HALL came to his death accidentally. HALL is single and was born at Cardston on Sept. 23rd, 1921. He is survived by his mother and three brothers all of Cardston, Alta.

18. The Coroner was engaged in regards to this inquest for 4 hours on the 25th instant and 4 hours on the 26th instant. Transportation was furnished the jury by this detachment to view the scene of the accident.

19. Form "A" of the Alberta Coroner's Act was issued on the 25-6-48 by Coroner Jas. A. KEY, M.D., Cardston, Alta. On 26-6-48 the death was registered at Cardston, Alta. Internment taking place on 28-6-48 in Cardston Cemetery. Confirmation copies of telegram forwarded to the Officer Commanding, Lethbridge Sub-Division advising of death and inquest attached hereto.

Re: Surplus Boiler - Classroom Blocks.
Blood and St. Paul's Residential Schools.

Reference your letter, file 103-2-5 (E) of the 4th instant regarding the above.

The possibility of using these boilers to heat the classroom blocks was gone into thoroughly when estimates on heating were being obtained, and the idea was abandoned as being more costly and inconvenient than heating from existing boilers.

In the first place, there are no radiators in either building and these would have to be purchased in any event. To install the surplus boilers would mean special boiler rooms and special coal bins at each School, at a terrific cost - it might also mean additional help to tend these boilers. Existing boilers are adequate in capacity to handle this increased load, with the addition of a stoker at the St. Paul's School - the St. Mary's R.C. School already has a stoker. DIRECTOR, LANDS and DEVELOPMENT SERVICES BRANCH.

Blood Indian Residential School.
St. Paul's Indian Residential School.

It is understood that a verbal request has been made for the sending of one of your Heating Engineers to visit these two schools which are situated some few miles apart in the Blood Indian Agency, Cardston, Alberta.

I appreciate the promptitude with which this request has been met. We have moved two Air Force buildings from nearby camps and have them now set up on full basement foundations at these schools. These buildings were former Link Trainer units and are already fitted up with classrooms. They will provide ideal classroom blocks at these two schools.

By converting the present classrooms into extra dormitories and by using the new classroom blocks, we will be able to provide accommodation for many more children at each of these schools. At present we are not providing any educational facilities whatsoever for over 100 children on this reserve.

Our Superintendent of Education found on his recent visit that the only serious problem now remaining before these classroom blocks can be opened is that of heating them. Our Regional Supervisor for Alberta and the local Indian Superintendent both made strong representations that a heating engineer should recommend the best way in which these buildings can be heated, in view of the magnitude of the tenders which will probably be involved.

Our field officials are agreed that the calling in of local heating contractors would not have solved the problem.
as each one would have presented his own ideas on the solution of the problem. Only the visit of a heating engineer will provide a sound and satisfactory solution. Therefore, the prompt sending of a heating engineer by your Branch will be appreciated, not only by our Headquarters officials, but also by our field officials.

Acting Director.

TENDERS, to be entitled to consideration, shall,

(1) Be made upon the form provided therefor, and shall be forwarded, duly sealed, and in the envelope attached thereto, on or before the time above limited.

(2) Be signed by the tenderer or tenderers as the case may be, in their respective handwritings, with the designated occupation and post office address. In the case of a company, the President, or other official having authority to bind the company, shall sign, and the corporate seal shall be affixed.

In the case of a partnership, each and every partner in the organization shall sign the tender, and in the event that such partnership shall be awarded a contract for the work, the partners will be jointly and severally bound in the contract agreement.

(3) Be accompanied by the required security deposit in amount stated in Tender Form. The amount of such security deposit will be returned to the unsuccessful tenderers as soon as the contract is awarded, or in case no tenders are accepted.

In the case of a Contractor's tender being accepted, the amount of the security deposit will be retained until such time as he has completed the contract work to the satisfaction of the Department.

(4) Have all blank spaces completely filled in, and shall give all information requested.

Tenderers shall submit with their tenders a statement of such works as they have previously undertaken similar to that on which they are tendering, giving details of the type of building and construction, location and present ownership.

Tenderers shall state whether or not all materials are of Canadian manufacture.

Tenderers shall include in their tender price all sales or special taxes in force at the time the tender is submitted.

Tenderers shall investigate and examine the site, everything and every condition affecting the work, and shall base their tenders on their own examination, knowledge, information and judgment, and not upon any statement, representation or information made or given by any officer or representative of the Department.

Tenderers should communicate with Mr. G. H. Gooderham, Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies, at Calgary, Alberta, or Mr. R. D. Ragan, Superintendent, Indian Agency, Cardston, Alberta, and arrange to inspect the classroom blocks concerned.

Should a tenderer fail, within fifteen days of the date of notification of acceptance of his tender, to execute the contract form, the tenderer's security deposit shall be forthwith forfeited absolutely to His Majesty.

The Minister reserves the right to reject any or all tenders and the lowest tender will not necessarily be accepted.

Department of Mines and Resources, Indian Affairs Branch, OTTAWA, Ont.

Re: St. Mary's R.C. School - Classroom Block.
Blood Indian Reserve.

Mr. Ralph Weston and myself have thoroughly gone into the building of a coal bin and boiler room with 30' chimney for the above Classroom Block, and I attach hereto Mr. Weston's estimate for doing the job, which amounts to $1,675.00. In submitting this tender Mr. Weston advises that he would much prefer to work on a cost-plus basis; either the Department or himself to pay for all material, excavation and so forth, Mr. Weston to furnish all labour and receive a 25% bonus computed on the cost of labour only. Added to this cost would be 10¢ per mile transportation charges for himself and his crew.

We are enclosing two plans of this coal bin and boiler room, as we believe it should be built. There is an existing lean-to on the building without floor or foundation, and we believe this lean-to is worth salvaging. We propose to build a concrete foundation for the coal bin and boiler room, as called for on the plan, and then to extend the existing lean-to to the edge of this foundation as shown on our enclosed sketch. By putting a door in this extension, and a railing on the reinforced concrete top of the boiler room, with steps to this top, it will give us an ideal building for any use to which we wish to put it. To do this will necessitate making the coal bin a bit larger than shown on the Department plan, but we believe this would still leave plenty of space in the boiler room. The contractor suggests moving the chimney away from the valley of the roof as shown in the Departmental plan, to eliminate danger of run-off water. As we understand it, this coal bin and boiler room must be completed before heating contractors can commence work; however, this cement work cannot be done until we have warmer weather unless the Department are prepared to pay an increased cost. May we have your criticisms and suggestions, therefore, regarding our enclosed plan, and any other suggestions which you deem advisable.

At the same time, can you please advise whether or not the Department contemplate lining the basement of the classroom block and whether or not this and other work - mainly electrical, can be proceeded with on a cost-plus basis.

RDR/S

DEPUTY MINISTER

Re: Classroom Block, Blood Residential School

You will recall that approval was previously given to a tender for moving two buildings purchased from War Assets Corporation in order that they could be renovated for classroom blocks at the Blood and St. Paul's Residential Schools, Blood Indian Agency, Cardston, Alberta.

Mr. John Superintendent Regan, with the approval of Regional Supervisor Gooderham, suggests that the existing lean-to should be extended and placed on a foundation, in order to provide adequate space for a coal bin and boiler room.

Mr. R.D. Regan,
Superintendent, Indian Agency,
Cardston, Alberta.

We have your letter of the 28th ultimo suggesting the erection of a coal bin and boiler room in the classroom block of the Blood Residential School.

It is noted that Mr. Ralph Weston is prepared to supply the material and labour at a total cost of $1,678.00, and it is understood that this price will include all the work which you consider necessary.

We have submitted Mr. Weston's tender to the Minister for his approval. When it is received, you will be so advised.

In view of the expenditure that will be required in connection with the heating and plumbing contract, our funds are not sufficient to justify other expenditures, and consequently, we do not intend to line the basement of the classroom block. It should not be necessary to place an extensive electrical installation in this building, but in any case, we are not prepared to award the business on a cost plus basis. You may obtain a contract for the electrical work which you consider is absolutely essential, and submit it for our information.

It is noted that you refer to this school as "St. Mary's R.C. School". The official name of the R.C. School on the Blood Reserve is "Blood Indian Residential School". When forwarding correspondence regarding this school, in future, please refer to it by the latter name.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Re: Blood Indian Residential School
Blood Indian Reserve

On August 3, 1948, we submitted to you a tender from Mr. Ralph Weston, Cardston, Alberta, for the installation of two full basements for the classroom buildings being moved to the St. Paul's Residential School and the Blood Residential School, on the Blood Indian Reserve.

When Mr. Ralph Weston completed this work, the question was raised of joining the new classroom blocks with the main buildings, preparatory to the installation of the heating units required. Indian Superintendent Ragan was requested to have firm tenders obtained for the installation of a passageway from the main building to the classroom block at both the St. Paul's and the Blood Residential Schools.

Our information is that the weather closed in and Mr. Ragan apparently permitted Mr. Weston to begin the construction of the connecting passageway without the proper authority.

In a memorandum dated February 9, 1949, we submitted to you an account from Mr. Ralph Weston in the amount of $701.81, for the erection of the connecting tunnel from the main building of the St. Paul's Residential School to the classroom block at that school. Payment of this account was approved by your office.

Superintendent Ragan has now submitted an account from Mr. Ralph Weston in the amount of $2,428.02
for the erection of the tunnel from the main building of the Blood Residential School to the classroom block at that school. Owing to bad weather, Mr. Ragan apparently permitted Mr. Weston to begin the erection of the connecting passageway without first receiving proper authority.

In explanation of the considerably higher cost for the erection of the connecting tunnel at the Blood Residential School than at the St. Paul's School, Mr. Ragan points out that the classroom block at the Blood School had to be placed a much longer distance from the main building than at the St. Paul's School, in view of drainage requirements. On August 3, 1948, we submitted to you a tender from Mr. Ralph Weston, Cardston, Alberta, for the installation of two full basements for the classroom buildings being moved to the St. Paul's Residential School and the Blood Residential School, on the Blood Indian Reserve.

When Mr. Ralph Weston completed this work, the question was raised of joining the new classroom blocks with the main buildings, preparatory to the installation of the heating units required. Indian Superintendent Ragan was requested to have firm tenders obtained for the installation of a passageway from the main building to the classroom block at both the St. Paul's and the Blood Residential Schools.

Our information is that the weather closed in and Mr. Ragan apparently permitted Mr. Weston to begin the construction of the connecting passageway without the proper authority.

In a memorandum dated February 9, 1949, we submitted to you an account from Mr. Ralph Weston in the amount of $701.31, for the erection of the connecting tunnel from the main building of the St. Paul's Residential School to the classroom block at that school. Payment of this account was approved by your office.

Superintendent Ragan has now submitted an account from Mr. Ralph Weston in the amount of $2,428.02
for the erection of the tunnel from the main building of the Blood Residential School to the classroom block at that school. Owing to bad weather, Mr. Ragan apparently permitted Mr. Weston to begin the erection of the connecting passageway without first receiving proper authority.

In explanation of the considerably higher cost for the erection of the connecting tunnel at the Blood Residential School than at the St. Paul's School, Mr. Ragan points out that the classroom block at the Blood School had to be placed a much longer distance from the main building than at the St. Paul's School, in view of drainage requirements. The width of the corridor at the Blood School is wider than at the St. Paul's School, and in order to provide safety for the large number of children enrolled at the Blood School, Mr. Ragan also points out that Mr. Weston installed an outside double door exit from the passageway. He further states that Mr. Weston did a splendid job.

If this work had not been done by Mr. Weston it would have been necessary to have the tunnel built in order to carry the water and drainage pipes. As stated in my memorandum of February 9, Mr. Ragan has been written to concerning the issuing of authority for such contracts without first receiving official approval, and we feel confident that there will be no repetition of such matters.

I would, therefore, recommend that you authorise payment of the account in the amount of $2,428.02. Funds for this payment are being held in our appropriation for the fiscal year 1948-49.

Reference your letter of the 10th instant, file 750-5 (E.l) and the request for a laundry press for the Blood Indian Residential School.

Having in mind the monies allocated for this school and equipment that must be purchased, Father LeFranco and I have gone over everything very carefully and have mutually agreed on the following expenditures:

**Equipment:**

- Stove (Tenders attached) $622.00
- Linoleum (Tenders Attached) $748.00
- Built-in Refrigerator (Tenders Att.) $1100.00
- Necessary construction work, material and wiring for same $300.00
- Showers for boys' and girls' baths $250.00

Total $3080.00

**Repairs:**

- Patch cement floors in boys' playroom and girls' bath $500.00

In this expenditure you will note there is nothing left for a laundry press and the Principal and I have agreed that the work as outlined is more urgent, and the press will have to wait.

**Stove:** Reference your letter 750-5 (E.l) of March 25th. Enclosed are two quotations, one from General Steel Wares and one from Electrical Wholesalers. It is respectfully requested that Coal Range No. RO SL at a price of $622.00 f.o.b. Lethbridge, Alta., and with three ovens and left hand firebox be ordered from the Electrical Wholesalers Ltd., 532 - 7th Ave. West, Calgary. This stove can be shipped to Lethbridge by C.P.R. and picked up there by the school truck.

**Linoleum:** This is badly needed for cement playground floors in the main school building and will save wear and tear on shoe leather, and serves as well as being much cleaner and quieter. Two quotations are submitted for this 400 square yards of linoleum. One quotation from J.H. Ashdown Ltd. at $1.97 sq. yd. and one from Breck Co. Ltd., Calgary at $1.97 sq. yd. It is respectfully requested that 400 sq. yds. A gauge, Brown battleship linoleum be
ordered at $1.87 sq.yd., or $745.00. This line can be picked up in Calgary, by the School truck to save freight.

Refrigerator:- The present refrigerator or cold box at this school is adequate for milk and small articles of food only. A Walk-in freezer, where large quantities of meat and other perishables can be kept is essential as this school do their own killing of beef and pork and must have adequate space to keep it. We have an extra room off the kitchen where this freezer can be located and it is respectfully requested that an expenditure of $1410.00 be allowed at once for the installation; the school will bear any costs over and above this amount.

We recommend that the enclosed tender of the Bruce Robinson Electric Ltd., of Calgary, in the amount of $1110.00, be accepted for the equipment installed plus insulation. It is also requested that an accountable cheque of $300.00 be forwarded this office toward building the Walk-in cooler, applying insulation, installing plumbing, wiring etc. Local labour will be supplied and the accountable advance will be used to pay wages as far as it will go after which the school will take over.

Showers:- It is our wish to install showers in the boys and girls' bathrooms and an amount of $250.00 is left for this. Tenders will be secured and forwarded for this work in the near future.

Repairs:- The repairing of the cracked and heaving cement floors of this school was begun last year, and is not near finished. We have reserved the total amount allowed for repairs - $600.00 for repairing and patching the cement floors in the boys' and girls' bathrooms. Tenders will be submitted for this necessary work at a later date.

We hope that the Department will agree with our plan of spending funds allocated for this school this fiscal year. Father LaFrance is very co-operative and has agreed to do much work at the school from his own funds. It would be appreciated if authority could be given for this work as soon as possible. We would especially like to begin work on the Walk-in freezer at once.

(R.D. Ragas)
Superintendent

July 7th, 1949.

Mr. Bernard F. Neary
Sup. of W. Training,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Mr. Neary,

I must first thank you for the kind offer of assisting financially to advance our provincial champion boxer to the Dominion finals. Unfortunately, the class he was in was not competing in Vancouver. However I hope to be able in the near future to send you a picture of this Indian Boy who has shown great ability.

The work on the classroom block is at a standstill. We are expecting the "go ahead" signal from Ottawa. I fear that if the work is not continued immediately, the classrooms will not be ready by September. I do hope that we will soon be favoured with a favourable answer from you, telling us to finish the whole thing.

I plan to have two classrooms in the basement, and I am enclosing a diagram of what divisions we plan to have in that basement. The classrooms would no doubt be dull, and even unsanitary, due to humidity if they were not finished. So would the sewing room, and the kitchen. The woodwork-shop could stay as it is. 5000 ft of stoneboard at $55.00 a thousand would take care of the material, labour and lumber partitions extra. I only wish that it would be possible for you, to see for yourself the necessity of those partitions and the finishing of the basement which we consider a minimum.
I was given to understand by Fr. Plourde O.M.I., that you could supply us with women lay teachers from the Maritimes. I already have on the teaching staff five teachers. One more would be required. The Grey Nuns are unable to give us an additional one. Would you be so kind as to give me the address or assist me in any way in getting a teacher. We could provide accommodation (room and board) for a teacher (single).

Hoping that you will give us the pleasure of your visit soon.

I remain

Yours truly,

M.J. Lafrance
O.M.I.

Rev. Maurice Lafrance O.M.I.
Principal.
Department of Mines and Resources, Indian Affairs Branch, OTTAWA.

I have your letter (Airmail) of the 13th instant, file number 750-5(E.), and also Mr. Phelan's letter of the 9th June, regarding closing in the basement of the Classroom Block with insulation board at the Blood Indian Residential School.

I certainly agree that all of this work is most necessary to protect the basement of the Classroom Blocks from the extreme cold weather and from frost covering on the inside of the walls. I would recommend insulating board be applied on all outside walls to do a first-class job. I have contacted Mr. R. Weston who is at the present preparing a tender for this necessary work at both Schools and I shall submit these with a requisition as soon as it is received.

I am returning Fr. LaFrance's letter as requested.

(R.D. Regan)
Superintendent.

Re: Blood R.C., Indian Residential School.

The storage basement of the above school, which is a room approximately 20' x 40' below the basement of the main school has no concrete floor and is getting in such a state that it is dangerous to the health of the children in the building and dangerous to the main building itself. The pillars which hold up the basement floor above are badly rotted; the dirt floor is wet and smells sour and musty.

As this room is used as storage for food stuffs and other materials at the school and as the pillars must be repaired to safeguard the main building I have asked Mr. Ralph Weston to give me a tender on cleaning out this storage basement, including the musty wet soil, laying a gravel sub-floor with a complete 5 inch concrete floor over this and to replace all rotted pillars.

I have your letter of the 31st of October file 750-5 (E 1) regarding purchase orders 48240 and 47157 and stating that it is not your policy to cancel purchase orders after so much time has elapsed.

The new Principals of the schools, as space was limited, requested that double deck bunks be supplied instead of beds. As the Parkhill Bedding was prepared to supply the double deck bunks and as these double deck bunks were more useful than the cots and as the substitution of the double deck bunks for the cots would save the Government over $328.00 we certainly did not anticipate refusal of the exchange from the Department.

Before our telegram of the 27th of October asking for authority for this substitution the double deck bunks and mattresses had already been ordered from Parkhill Bedding and had already been shipped on receipt of your letter of October 31st. The bunks have now been delivered, the children are sleeping on them, we have saved valuable space in the schools and valuable money for the Department.

We are sorry that we have again over-stepped our authority but with pressure of other business, lack of staff, etc., etc., we hope that you can understand our position. I am submitting herewith two vouchers covering purchase orders no. 48240 and 47157; you will note that voucher no. 748 on purchase order 48240 is $328.65 less than the actual purchase order. Re: Blood R. C. Residential School

The bake oven at the above school has been giving us a great deal of trouble as of late, in that it will not build up and maintain temperature and smokes badly. To attempt to remedy this situation we called in Hall Brothers, the only Plumber in Cardston and had them work the oven over. They told me that the oven was worn and burned out but that they believed that a new fire box would make it serviceable. As bread must be baked, I told them to repair the oven as an emergency measure so that it could again be used.

Hall Brothers installed a complete new fire box, Y pipe, and made other small repairs to the cost of $375.25 for the oven and still no build up temperature or hold it, and on windy days, which is practically 90% of the time here, the oven smokes so badly that it drives the sister cooks from the kitchen. We have again had Hall Brothers look at the oven and they now tell me that they have done all they possibly can to make this oven work and that the only solution is a new oven.

I have asked the Rev. Father LaFrance his views and he agrees with the Plumbers and requests that a 150 loaf capacity coal fire oven be purchased immediately. The Rev. Principal is now buying bread and if it is at all possible to replace the oven at the Blood R. C. Indian Residential School this fiscal year, we would certainly recommend that it be done.

R. D. Ryan,
Superintendent,
Blood Indian Reserve.

Dear Mr. Ragan:

Re: Expenditure Residential Schools

I have a letter from Colonel Neary stating that you have assumed considerable expenditure on the two schools on the Blood Reserve, without first of all having authority to do so. He sites specifically the instance of an installation of a new fire box, etc., in a bake oven of the N.C. School, at a cost of $375.25.

You are well aware that this is not the only instance, or in my opinion, the most flagrant case where you have not asked for authority before proceeding with the purchase or repairs which amounted to a considerable expenditure. It should be unnecessary for me to again remind you that such procedure is wrong despite the fact that you have always had a very logical explanation for doing so. In future, you shall make no expenditure without first consulting this office, or wiring direct to the Superintendent of Education for authority. If you appeal to this office in the first instance, I can tell you now that I will not authorize any expenditure of major proportion, unless it is extremely urgent, without first wiring the Superintendent.

I regret that this is necessary, and I am satisfied that Colonel Neary has been long-suffering for the reason that he believed that you were so enthusiastic and sincere in your desire to see proper conditions and progress in these schools, and delayed bringing it to my attention until now.

Yours truly,

LaFrance Foamite extinguishers are labelled by the Underwriters' Laboratories for use on fires in wood, paper, cloth gasolines, oils, greases, paints, etc., or combinations of same. One 25 gallon Model C.A. Foamite extinguisher discharges over 25 gallons of fire smothering Firefoam in one minute at an effective range of 25 feet. The range allows an operator to stand back in safety and comfort and the rapid application of volume allows him to smother a large fire very quickly. Foamite Firefoam clings to any burning surface, vertical or horizontal, and floats on volatile liquids forming an airtight blanket which extinguishes the fire by both cooling and smothering.

Foamite Firefoam is as non-damaging as clear water, will not irritate the delicate membranes of the eye, ear or throat and can be swallowed without ill effect. While it will dampen slightly it does not soak and can be safely used around patterns and ply woods without causing warping. Foamite Firefoam may stain slightly office stationery but the information recorded thereon will not be obliterated. To remove Fireform simply scrape off excess and allow remainder to dry, then brush or wipe off.

The Carbon tetrachloride (vaporizing liquid) type of extinguisher should only be used out in the open where there is abundant fresh air and room for the operator to keep clear of the gases. Carbon tetrachloride has no quenching effect on fire. It turns to gases when in contact with heat diluting the oxygen in the surrounding air. The two chief gases formed are chlorine and phosgene, both are military poisons and both are corrosive, and the harm they may do is not immediately apparent. Breathing these gases is exceedingly dangerous, slight amounts over a period of time cause hardening of the liver, amount sufficient to make a person dizzy leave one susceptible to pneumonia for a period of six weeks and heavier concentration can cause death within a few hours.

Re: Blood R. C. Residential School

I wish to refer to your letter of November 24/49, file 750-5 (E.1), regarding electrical wiring at the above school. Since my letter regarding the electrical wiring situation at this school the outside wire and poles gave way during one of our bad blizzards and the wire and poles are now buried in 6 feet of snow. This is a 220 volt line and something must be done to put this wiring up out of danger before moisture seeps into the wires. Steel vs. Brick Ovens

Steel Ovens have during the past ten years come into great favor because first, of the great improvements made in their construction and secondly, because they are much cheaper than the smaller and medium size brick oven. The smaller size brick oven is more expensive to install an work with than the steel oven. However, the building of a large expensive stationary brick oven often in rented or leased premises.

Steel ovens have another very important advantage and that is their portability. They can be removed from one location to another without any loss of time whereas against brick ovens, where very little can be saved except when they have to be torn down and re-erected.

The building of a good first class brick oven, especially one which will stand up to the severe conditions of temperature fluctuations and heat stress, requires a great deal of skill in design and foundations, general vibration, wear and tear, is very costly and often many times the cost of the most portable steel or combination type of oven.

Experience has shown that a brick oven as described above will last at least fifteen years and with trimmings and high freight can easily exceed $350.00. Some of the heavy duty ovens built by Kipp-Kelly in Western Canada cost from $1000.00 to $6000.00.

Large semi-portable steel ovens can be shipped at costs considerably less than $200.00 and is roughly half that of the average first class brick oven.

It is therefore, much more economical for the smaller baker to install the steel oven, which will give him the same capacity and enable him at the stage when his business requires capacity in excess of what is able to be handled by the brick oven.

We have seen with our own eyes the value of brick ovens. We build brick ovens that are second to none on the market and sell exclusively to those who require large capacities and where the necessary capital is available. We believe however, in building only brick ovens which are properly designed and have enough bricks in them, that they will store heat and maintain a high baking temperature all at the same time stand up for a good many years.

This Bulletin is, therefore, devoted only to the description of our semi-portable and all portable hot air and electric ovens.

METHOD OF RAVEN

The majority of the portable ovens, except the small electric ones, are built on single leaf pans, strapped in fours, whose outside sizes do not exceed 4' x 8'. These pans are usually constructed of old cuttings of single pans set closely together or double pans, not strapped. Our ovens, however, are therefore, constructed of double leaf pans. Our double deck oven holds actually only 102 single leaves, strapped in fours, but the oven is built so that the pans may be closed together. Some oven builders still use the old method of building them on the same conservative basis, as above.

This means that our 300 leaf double deck oven measures 7' x 14', while the same size brick oven will hold only 340 leaves, so we build a 302 leaf oven whose inside deck dimensions are 9'6" x 7'1".

GUARANTEE

We guarantee every oven built and designed by us to perform exactly as built and designed, to be economical in the use of fuel, either coke or wood, and to be free from defects in materials. Our portable ovens built of standard steel plate or special cast iron, are guaranteed against rusting, warping, cracked metal, etc., and can supply ovens also with enamelled or plated exteriors, etc.

FINANCING

Our financing department will arrange, if required, an easy payment plan for purchasing Kipp-Kelly Semi-Portable Hot Air Double Deck Ovens, thus enabling bakers having limited means and allowing the ovens to pay for themselves.

Kipp-Kelly Electric Ovens

Our electric oven possesses two distinct and important features; each deck has its own independent and individual top and bottom heating element and both top and bottom are completely covered by a smooth enamel finish, the best available.

The fact that each deck is heated by its own elements means that in a two deck oven, even different kinds of goods can be baked at the same time, all different temperatures. For instance, the bottom deck could be heated to 350° F., the lower deck to 300° F., and the top deck to 250° F. Each deck is heated independently, thus eliminating hot spots which will not transmit heat. Independent deck construction is also economical, as a baker can easily replace any deck, without having to replace the entire oven.

There facilities are not available in the case of an ordinary oven where between deck elements serve a double purpose, both top and bottom heat. The deck which is being heated by the deck above is a very common construction, even for the oven builder but not for the baker.

Our top element is exposed in the open deck. We have a special reason for this, as it makes the baking of light goods easier. When quick top heat was required to put color on some goods being baked, the baker would have to send that heat down through a layer of brick it would take considerably longer and would do more harm than good. With our open top heat is applied when it is wanted and as soon as the current is turned off the oven is allowed to cool.

Having the top elements exposed in the deck is not in any way harmful, as they will last for years. We know of ovens which have had their elements replaced fifteen years of service, are still in good condition.

We have always believed that the only way to get an absolutely even distribution of heat is to have the elements cover the whole inside deck top and bottom. This is why we use two elements in each deck which cover only a small space, hot and cold spots are bound to result.

Our electric oven construction is much more expensive than other types, but it is our desire to produce the finest oven possible, one superior in design, flexible and economical in operation and which will enable the baker to turn out a superior product.

Our Heavy Duty Electric Ovens can also be supplied with brick lining on the sides of the decks, usable for additional storage space. While this will cut down the capacity somewhat, some bakers have found that the extra storage space is extremely valuable for baking light goods after the bread has been baked, without additional currents.

We manufacture every part of our electric ovens in our own shop with the exception of the switches. This enables us to closely supervise every part, assuring the highest Canadian workmanship and construction throughout.

Memorandum:

DEPARTMENTAL PURCHASING AGENT

Re: Purchase Order 47157, Your File 95255-4-38
Blood R.C. Indian Residential School

The above placed an order with the Parkhill Bedding Limited for 30 beds and 30 mattresses for the above mentioned school. Before this equipment was delivered, there was a change in Principals, and the new Principal decided that it would be preferable to have double decker bunks, which would occupy less floor space.

In the case of the Blood Residential School, securing the bunks made it possible to provide sleeping accommodation for 10 more children than by providing the 30 beds. This change was made by the Principal himself without first consulting the Department, although it is understood that he consulted the Indian Superintendent. We have pointed out to both these officials that they had no authority to make the change without first obtaining official approval.

However, the bunks are now in use at the school, and I would appreciate it if you would change the Purchase Order to read bunks instead of beds, in order that the account will be accepted by the Treasury Branch. I attach the account and you will notice that the firm charge Sales Tax and that the Principal paid the difference between the total of the original Purchase Order, namely $772.50, and the total of the Voucher, namely $780.00.

Bernard F. Neary,

Father Lafrance

I have been instructed to advise you that the Department will not, in future, assume responsibility for expenditures incurred without express authority first had and obtained from the Department.

If an occasion should arise at your school when certain work should be performed, including the repair and upkeep of and alterations to buildings or purchase or repair of equipment, or any other expenditure which you consider should be borne by the Department, either in whole or in part, you must first contact the Superintendent of the Blood Agency for authority to perform the work or to make the purchase. It may follow that the Superintendent himself will then have to obtain authority from his headquarters. His authority to make local purchases is very limited, and invariably he must seek higher authority unless the occasion for the expenditure is a real emergency. An emergency occurs when immediate action is required that cannot wait for wired communication and authority from either the Regional Supervisor or Ottawa. Such occasions, I am sure you agree, arise very rarely.

Although it is obvious that departmental estimates completed each summer for the following fiscal year should be complete insofar as they concern your school, you understand of course, that because an item is placed in the Blood Agency Estimates for Educational vote is no assurance whatsoever that the expenditure will be allowed. It is often necessary to scale down such estimates at Ottawa to an amount that we can reasonably expect the taxpayers of Canada to bear.

Dear Mr. MacKay:

If I am writing to you today it is because my letters to Mr. Neary seem to have been intercepted in some way. Since the beginning of the year I have written three letters, and up to now have received no acknowledgement.

Last summer I was informed that we would have to increase the pupilage by some fifty pupils. This of course meant alterations and enlargements of dormitories and new facilities for play-rooms. All this I have done with the tacit approval of Mr. Gooderham and the Superintendent.

It seemed only logical that it was necessary to have separate play-rooms for both senior and junior girls and boys and that these new rooms would need toilets. I am sure that I would have been condemned by Ottawa had I packed 130 girls in a single playroom 30x30. Same situation for the boys.

In all this I acted in good faith, now I see that I am considered just short of a criminal at Ottawa. What is more, I was given to understand that I should do my utmost to provide better class facilities, and improve recreational program etc.... It would be too long to tell you all that has been done in that time; I will only mention that I have built a gymnasium 90 X 50 without any special aid from the Department. All assistance was refused.

As for classes, things have been improved to such an extent that the pupils, believe it or not, like their class work. As proof of that, in the past year we had over thirty cases of truancy, while this year we did not have a single case. What is more surprising is that there were only five pupils late in coming back after the Christmas holidays, this was because of illness.

It is rather discouraging now to see that I am condemned for having made improvements at the school and that I am refused all assistance when I was ordered to take more pupils. I felt it only logical to go ahead and provide accommodation for them. The absolutely
indispensable alterations and improvements amounted to some $4,000. All I am asking the Department is to help me with at least half the amount.

Would you kindly let me know if any money has been voted this year for reparations to our school. If so, could part of that money cover the expenses of last year?

I was given to understand that we could requisition to Ottawa for a 16 mm projector. Please let me know if I am right in assuming that we can obtain from the Department either a Victor 60 or B & H 16mm sound projector.

In closing I can assure you dear Mr. MacKay, that I have only one thing at heart and that is to make our children happy so they will study well and eventually become good Canadian citizens.

Very sincerely yours,

Maurice J. [signature]

I wish to refer to your letter of March 29th, file 104/6-1-1, which quoted a telegram from Col. Neary regarding exchange of a Bake Oven and authorizing up to $1000.00 for structural changes at the Blood School to handle the larger Bake Oven.

Father Lafrance and I have gone over this problem thoroughly and we have the following recommendation to offer. It is suggested that the present Manual Training Shop in the new classroom block of this school be made into the Bake Room. This room lends itself very well to this as the large chimney of the classroom block is on one of the walls, the room is well lighted and very handy to the dining room and kitchen, the straight changes required to make this room into a Bake Room would be practically nil. This would, of course, provide other room for Manual Training, interest in which is growing very rapidly at this school. For this we mean to build an entirely new work shop behind the present school gymnasium, this shop to be designed for all modern power tools and so forth. This new work shop, of course, will cost much more than the $1000.00 allowed by the Department, but Father Lafrance is willing to pay all costs of this building above the $1000.00 from school funds.
We whole heartedly recommend this procedure to the Department as it will give a much needed building for the Manual Training Class, provide beautiful, large, well lighted Bake Room and all at a minimum cost to the Department. If authorized, it is recommended that the $1000.00 allotted be forwarded this office as an accountable cheque so that Father Lafance may begin construction as soon as possible and during the holidays.

Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies,
507 Public Building,
Calgary, Alberta.

Re: Bake Oven,
Blood R. C. Residential School.

Following discussion in your office regarding the above I wish to elaborate a bit on the proposed changes at the Blood R. C. School. Possibly the Department misunderstood when we suggested that the Bake room of this school should be transferred to the classroom block; we should have stated to the basement of the classroom block. In our opinion this basement room is an ideal bake shop, as stated in my previous letter, as it is well lighted, roomy and very handy to the Dinning room and kitchen with practically no structural changes required.

I am attaching hereto a rough sketch of the proposed Manual Training Shop to be constructed to house the equipment in the Class room basement. As you know the Rev. Father Lafrance has agreed to construct this building himself, providing the Department allow him $1000.00 toward labour. Father Lafrance has the necessary lumber on hand at the present time to build this shop and if the Department would approve and could forward the $1000.00 as an accountable cheque, construction could begin immediately. It is proposed to hire a Contractor from Cardston to build the shell of the building so that it would be weather tight; it is then our plan to have the Manual
Training Class complete the inside of the building as to insulation, finish, tool and lumber racks etc. This would not only save construction costs but would give the class valuable training. When and if this building is completed it is Father Lafrances plan to secure more power equipment.

This arrangement is again recommended for your consideration and it is hoped that an accountable advance of the $1000.00 contribution by the Department can be forwarded without delay.

Yours very truly,

R. D. [Signature]
Superintendent
Blood Indian Reserve,
Dept. of Citizenship & Immigration.

R.C. School.

Cardston, Alta., April 6th, 1938.

Sir:

I wish to state that I have today forwarded by express, addressed to you, the two lamp shades mentioned in my February and March reports, being the exclusive work of pupils in the senior girls room, Blood R.C. Indian Residential School.

The two shades are described as follows:
The octagonal one is shellacked after painting, and the round shade is smudge proofed with a coating of turpentine.

The value placed on these for sale is, octagonal one from $8.00 to $10.00, and the round one $7.00 to $8.00. We think this value is not too high for the quality and the idea behind the making.

I may say that all the designs are free hand, no tracing at all, and apart from direction by the Teacher, Sister Le Forest, and the Rev. Father Charon, the assistant Principal, the work is entirely that of the pupils, and is done in their art class and spare time.

Your interest in the sale of these will be appreciated as we believe that it will be an incentive to these pupils.

Your obedient servant,

R.A. Hoey, Esq.,

It is my hope that Miss Moodie will be able to dispose of these shades at the prices mentioned in your communication.

Yours truly,

Extract from Inspector Schmidt's report on the St. Mary's Indian Residential School dated November 23, 1938:

MANUAL TRAINING:

The older boys assist with different chores around the barns and buildings. There is no regular manual training shop for carpentry or mechanical work. The Principal is arranging to open a shop in a fair-sized frame building near the main building. This has a brick chimney, and he intends installing a coal stove to heat same, as soon as he can procure one. I looked over the building, and found it quite suitable as regards size and lighting. Brother Turcotte, to whom the Principal refers as "Supervisor of Manual Training" will be in charge. At present they have no tools, and I was asked if it would be in order to forward a requisition for same. My reply was, that I would certainly recommend same, and that I believe the Department would give the request their kind consideration. I expect to receive the requisition shortly, when it will be forwarded to the Department.

The girls are receiving a good training in domestic and household work. They make their own and the boys' clothing, and mend same. During the summer months they go daily, in groups of seven, under the supervision of one of the sisters, and milk cows. This work is not carried on during the winter months.

(Sgd.) C. Pant, Schmidt,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Alberta Inspectorate.
