Report for month of February.

Both schools were visited during the month attendance at both being at the full roll of the registers.

One truant from the R.C. school was away two days and returned to the school by myself on a Sunday, being picked up while away at the North end of the reserve bringing in a patient to our hospital.

I was rather impressed by the effort made at the Blood R.C. school by the principal to provide some industry for the older girls, and find that he has established a connection with the local druggist, Mr. H.L. Higgs, who has a store at Waterton Park, for a certain type of Indian made goods of a saleable type, and I viewed a number of the articles already made for this store for the coming tourist season, and they reflect great care on the part of the instructors. This work is being done in the evenings by the older girls who are enjoying this innovation. A description of the articles being made is attached as a note to my school report for this particular school.

J.E. Pugh.
Indian Agent.
You will realize that the Department's wishes in regard to manual training can only be carried out with the co-operation of yourself and I feel certain that you recognize the value of this training and that the school management will provide at their own expense the space required for the classes and arrange to have some member of the staff follow the curriculum that you will receive.

I understand that you have small space available for manual training purposes and Mr. Doucet advises me that it might be possible to use the basement in the Church. It is also expected that you will arrange for a member of the staff to teach the work.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
Ottawa,
August 8, 1941.

Reverend Sir:

As I advised you in my letter of March 24 the Department attempted to emphasize the importance of manual training in Indian schools by having Mr. A.J. Doucet of this Branch visit your school during the past few months. At that time he outlined the policy of the Branch regarding manual training and endeavoured to explain the matter as fully as possible to your teachers.

Due to present conditions it will not be possible for the Department to allow any large amount in order to encourage the teaching of manual training in your school. However, it is hoped that you will co-operate with us in having this work commence during the academic year 1941-42.

To assist you in this regard Mr. Doucet is preparing a curriculum covering woodwork especially which it is hoped will be followed at your school during the coming academic term.

At the time of his visit Mr. Doucet made a careful check on the equipment that you have and has made definite recommendations to me regarding the additional equipment which he considers should be supplied in order to carry out the curriculum that you will receive. The cost of these tools will be borne by the Department and in addition you may expend an amount of $25.00 for necessary material.

Rev. P.A. Charron, O.M.I.,

Extract from Inspector Schmidt's report on the Blood R.C. Indian Residential School dated February 10, 1942.

MANUAL TRAINING

Good work is being done in this line: It has been found that the work shop -- a separate building from the main school building -- is cold in winter and rather difficult to heat, for which reason work in this room is not being carried on during cold weather. The Principal has prepared plans for enlarging this building, which will double the floor space. This will be properly finished, lined inside and insulated, and a proper floor laid. When arranged, it will comprise a number of ordinary carpenter's work benches, a forge, anvil, vice and bench, etc., and will have double doors to allow a truck, tractor, or other smaller-sized farm machinery to be brought inside for repairing or overhauling at any time of the year. The shop is now equipped with an electric welding unit. The tools now in use are well cared for and kept in separate lockers. There is a fair supply of material -- boards, planks, etc. -- on hand. This is neatly piled in different sizes. Good work is being done in this shop.

A new wind-break -- 8-foot board fence -- was built around the winter stock feed plot this summer. The older boys helped with this work, which is very well done.

Memorandum of an inquiry into the cause and circumstances of the death of Donald Shade, Pupil No. 204, of the Blood Reserve Indian Residential School at Blood Reserve, who died at Blood Reserve Hospital on May 20th, 1935.

INSTRUCTIONS

When a pupil of an Indian Residential School dies, the Principal is required to inform the Indian Agent at once.

On receipt of the Principal's notice the Indian Agent shall convene a Board of Inquiry, consisting of himself as Chairman, the Principal of the Residential School, and the Medical Officer who attended the deceased pupil. These members of the Board shall, in each other's presence, complete this memorandum, which shall then be forwarded to the Department of Indian Affairs, Ottawa, in one copy.

The Board of Inquiry shall, if at all practicable assemble within 48 hours of the pupil's death.

The parents or guardians of the deceased pupil shall be given notice of this inquiry and be permitted to attend it or to send a representative. They or their representative shall be asked if they wish to make a statement. In the event of their so wishing, their statement shall be attached to the report. The inquiry, however, shall not be delayed more than 72 hours after the time at which it would otherwise be held, to enable them to attend it.

If the Indian Agent is located at such a distance from the school as to make it impracticable for him to attend the Board, he shall request a responsible local resident to act for him. A suitable person for this duty would be a Justice of the Peace or a member of the Royal Canadian Mounted or Provincial Police. A more or less permanent arrangement of this kind might be necessary in some cases. The Department is prepared to pay a reasonable fee for this duty, on the Agent's recommendation. The report of the Board, in any case, must reach the Department through the Indian Agent's office.

This inquiry is not designed to take the place of, or prevent, any other inquiry, including an inquest, which may be required by law.

If the pupil died as the result of an accident, the Indian Agent is required to take the statements of the witnesses of the accident, and attach them to this memorandum.

Dear Mr. Pugh:

This boy had the measles at St. Mary's school about the ninth of this month. He was fully recovered and was attending school again. The measles were very mild being that of the German type.

INSTRUCTIONS

(1) The present form of certificate has been drawn up after consultation between the Dominion Bureau of Statistics and representatives of leading bodies in the medical profession. It has been approved by the Vital Statistics Section of the Canadian Public Health Association and also by the Deputy Registrar of births, deaths and marriages of each province.

(2) Physician's Statement of Cause of Death.—The morbid conditions relating to death are divided on the certificate into two groups. In Group I are those related to immediate cause of death; those in Group II, those causally related thereto. In most cases only one of these groups will be filled in. During certification is not desirable to enter more than one cause. In cases where this can be considered as adequate (see Example I), but where the physician finds it necessary to record more than one cause it is important that these be stated in the position provided on the form as indicative of their mutual relationship. This information is sought so that the selection of the cause for tabulation may be made in the light of the certifier's viewpoint:

(a) Name first the "Immediate Cause" of death, i.e. the disease, injury or complication which caused death (not mode of dying or terminal condition).

(b) Then give other morbid conditions (if any) of which it was the consequence, in order of causal relationship (due to) stating the most recent one first and then others in descending order.

(c) Entries under Group II should be reserved for "other important contributory morbid conditions" in those instances particularly in which death was due to a combination of maladies, none of which would have been fatal alone. In such cases the physician's judgment alone can afford a guidance to the tabulator.

(d) Use always accepted terms for morbid conditions and never record mere symptoms.

(e) Maternal Deaths.—Qualify all diseases resulting from childbirth, miscarriage or abortion by the word "Puerperal," e.g., puerperal septicemia. Distinguish between septicaemia originating in abortion and in childbirth.

(f) Cancer.—In all cases the organ or part first affected should be specified.

(g) Violent Deaths.—Coroners, medical examiners and physicians who certify to deaths from violent causes should always clearly indicate the fundamental distinction of whether the death was due to accident, assault or homicide, and then state the manner and nature of injury. The circumstances of each accident should be stated as fully as possible. Any automobile accident should always be designated as such.

INSTRUCTIONS

When a pupil of an Indian Residential School dies, the Principal is required to inform the
Indian Agent at once.

On receipt of the Principal's notice the Indian Agent shall convene a Board of Inquiry,
consisting of himself as Chairman, the Principal of the Residential School, and the Medical
Officer who attended the deceased pupil. These members of the Board shall, in each other's
presence, complete this memorandum, which shall then be forwarded to the Department of
Indian Affairs, Ottawa, in one copy.

The Board of Inquiry shall, if at all practicable assemble within 48 hours of the pupil's
death.

The parents or guardians of the deceased pupil shall be given notice of this inquiry and be
permitted to attend it or to send a representative. They or their representative shall be asked
if they wish to make a statement. In the event of their so wishing, their statement shall be
attached to the report. The inquiry, however, shall not be delayed more than 72 hours after
the time at which it would otherwise be held, to enable them to attend it.

If the Indian Agent is located at such a distance from the school as to make it imprac-
ticable for him to attend the Board, he shall request a responsible local resident to act for him.
A suitable person for this duty would be a Justice of the Peace or a member of the Royal
Canadian Mounted or Provincial Police. A more or less permanent arrangement of this kind
might be necessary in some cases. The Department is prepared to pay a reasonable fee for
this duty, on the Agent's recommendation. The report of the Board, in any case, must reach
the Department through the Indian Agent's office.

This inquiry is not designed to take the place of, or prevent, any other inquiry, including
an inquest, which may be required by law.

If the pupil died as the result of an accident, the Indian Agent is required to take the state-
ments of the witnesses of the accident, and attach them to this memorandum.

(1) The present form of certificate has been drawn up after consultation between the Dominion Bureau of Statistics and representatives of leading bodies in the medical profession which has been approved by the Vital Statistics Section of the Canadian Public Health Association and also by the Deputy Registrar of births, deaths and marriages of each province.

(2) Physician's Statement of Cause of Death.—The morbid conditions relating to death are divided on the certificate into two groups. In Group I are those related to the "Immediate Cause" of death, and in Group II, those not causally related thereto. In most cases a statement in Group I will constitute a valid certification; is not desired, the entry of a single cause being preferable in all cases where this can be regarded as adequate (see Example 1), but where the physician finds it necessary to record more than one cause, these should be stated in the order provided on the form as indicative of their mutual relationship. This information is sought so that the selection of the cause for tabulation may be made in the light of the certifier's viewpoint:

(a) Name first the "Immediate Cause" of death, i.e. the disease, injury or complication which caused death (not mode of dying or terminal condition).

(b) Then give other morbid conditions (if any) of which it was the consequence, in order of causal relationship (due to) stating the most recent one first and then others in order.

(c) Entries under Group II should be reserved for "other important contributory morbid conditions" in those instances particularly in which death was due to a combination of maladies, none of which would have been fatal alone. In such cases the physician's judgment alone can afford a guidance to the tabulator.

(d) Use always accepted terms for morbid conditions and never record mere symptoms.

(e) Maternal Deaths.—Qualify all diseases resulting from childbirth, miscarriage or abortion by the word "Puerperal," e.g., puerperal septicaemia. Distinguish between septicaemia originating in abortion and in childbirth.

(f) Cancer.—In all cases the organ or part first affected should be specified.

(g) Violent Deaths.—Coroners, medical examiners and physicians who certify to deaths from violent causes should always clearly indicate the fundamental distinction of whether the death was due to accident, suicide or homicide, and then state the manner and nature of injury. The circumstances of each accident should be stated as fully as possible, e.g., an automobile accident should always be designated as such.

Sir,

I have the honor to acknowledge your favor of the 8th inst., No. 866, referring to difficulties said to have occurred among the Indians at Saddle Lake, and requesting that the Methodist Church will use its utmost efforts with the Protestant Indians to prevent threatened violence.

In reply I beg to say that I was not aware "that a considerable portion of the Indians of the Bands mentioned belong to the Roman Catholic Church," but on the contrary have always understood that a very small number indeed profess that faith; on this point, however, it is possible I have been misinformed.

In former correspondence with the Indian Dep't, I have always understood it to be their settled policy to discourage the establishment of competing schools in the same Bands, unless the number was sufficiently large to necessitate such a division. If the number of Roman Catholic Indians is sufficient to entitle them to a school in accordance with the standing regulations of the Indian Department, I presume the way will be clear for the Commissioner to proceed in the usual way. At the same time I wish to say that for some time a disposition has been shown by authorities of the Roman Catholic Church to interfere with our missions wherever it was possible to do so, especially by establishing schools under Roman Catholic auspices, and from any information that is in my possession, I am disposed to think the present is a case in point.

It is true that Chief Pecan, and a large portion of his Band, reside at Whitefish Lake, but the settlement at Saddle Lake was formed by a detachment of the Whitefish Lake Indians, who were all connected with the Methodist Church, and have retained that connection to the present time. From what I know of these Indians, their general christian character, and their unserving loyalty to the Government during the North-West rebellion, the statement that they have "gone the length of threatening to burn any mission or school buildings which may be put up by the Roman Catholic Church on the Reserve," is one which I am unwilling to receive without the most positive evidence. I shall therefore put myself in communication at once with the Missionary in charge of the Saddle Lake station, and also with the Chairman of the District, so that the matter may be thoroughly sifted, and the truth brought to light.

In the meantime permit me to express the hope that no steps will be taken by the Department to force a division among the people at Saddle Lake until it is clearly ascertained that the request of the minority is one that comes clearly within the standing regulations of the Department in such cases.

I have the honor to be,

Sir,
Your obedient servant,
(Sgd) A. Sutherland,
Gen'l Sec'y.

Dear Doctor,

Having had very little or no time to reply sooner to your favor of the 14th of March, respecting the agitation which exists between the Protestant and Roman Catholic Indians, I now take this opportunity to do so. Several questions were put forth in that communication concerning this agitation which I will endeavor to answer.

In the summer of 1857, the year I was sent out to take this charge, the Priest, who is now stationed here, while at Onion Lake used to make frequent calls at this place (so I was told when I arrived) administering to the spiritual wants of their people. About that time there was a sort of religious awakening among the Indians in this place, and the people were in a somewhat unsettled state, there being no one whom they could look upon as instructor in things Divine. It happened that the Priest made his appearance first, and he embraces the opportunity of instilling their doctrines in the minds as well as in the hearts of the people. This, however, was only a temporary call.

The appointment to this mission being allotted to me by the Conference of that year, the Protestants were the first ones to have a teacher.

The people of the other persuasion naturally desired to have a teacher as well as the Protestants. This desire took the following effect: An invitation was extended to this Priest, which he of course accepted. May say at this juncture that the Band whose Reserve is joined to Pakan's Reserve is catholic almost in total; the Headman is the only Protestant among them. Before this Band extended an invitation to the Priest, they held Councils without the knowledge of their Chief (which was not done by the Protestants when they desired to have a teacher) wherein they decided to take such a step. The Chief of this Band did not know anything about these meetings, nor what was decided in them until the decision of his Band took effect in the arrival of the Priest within his reserve. Of course the Roman Catholic Indians on this Reserve (the one I am on) joined hands with the Band already mentioned towards securing a teacher of their persuasion. They secured one, and right early at that. He had not been in long until it was rumoured that he was not content with the situation, to be on the tail end of the Reserve (because it is like one, though in reality two distinct ones) did not suit his reverence, but he must needs be in the centre of it. When this intention was generally known, the Whitefish Indians came out in a body, held a Council wherein they expressed their unwillingness that the Roman Catholic Church should establish itself within their Reserve. It was held that no party had a right to establish itself without their consent. This is the opposition which is said to have come from Chief Pakan and his Band. Why should it not be so since this as well as the Whitefish Lake Reserve are under his Chieftainship? Besides they have been
made to understand that these Reserves are their private property. There never would have been any contention whatever had the Priest established himself in the Reserve which he first entered. This contention comes from no persecution whatever, nor from want of intolerance. But the spirit of arose from his insisting on planting himself where he is not allowed to. I think he would not have persisted in his idea had he not had countenance from others outside who are in authority.

At first it was said that whichever side had the majority, that side should win the case. But this they did not abide by, for as soon as they discovered that Pakan and his whole Band protested against the planting of the Roman Catholic Church in the heart of the Reserve, they wanted to exclude him and his band by making a sweeping statement that Chief Pakan and his Band had no right whatever to say in the matter.

Is it not to be wondered at that those who took an active part in the Rebellion, and who were put in jail for it for several months, are the ones who are using their energies and time toward the establishment of the said Church in the proposed site. When such men are the leading spirits in any project, one can hardly expect any good to come of it.

Before going any further may I be allowed to ask several questions. To whom does this Reserve belong? To the Government? To the Roman Catholic Church? To any other denomination that might be named? Or does it belong to the poor Indian?

Regarding the number of people in each party, there are sixty-seven Protestants, and forty-seven Roman Catholics, grown up people and children in each case within Pakan's Reserve. The number of children of school age are seventeen of the Protestants, together with three above the age which the Government has made the standard but who are attending, making a total of twenty; Roman Catholics nine, with one above school age. But counting the Chief of the other Band, the Protestants would number seventy-one, and Roman Catholics seventy-two. I give you these figures that you may know the exact number of children in each case on these two Reserves. As I understand the Priest took some names that do not belong to either Reserve. For instance, some half-breeds, French, and some Indians who have no home since the Rebellion.

As to the violence threatened. From the tenor of your communication this threatened violence seems to have been attributed to all the Protestant Indians. Such is not the case; but I believe one did say something to that effect in a bluff way while in hot discussion with the Indian Agent concerning this trouble. But they were unanimous in signing the following notice:

"We the undersigned do hereby notify the Rev. Father O'Meara that as we have sometime ago prohibited him from erecting any building on this place or inside this Reserve claimed and surveyed for our own property.

That if he still without our consent place any timber or lumber of any part of the aforesaid Reserve, we will haul the same away, and place it on the Reserve where he now is. No man has a right to build on any portion of this Reserve without our consent."

Yours obediently,

(Sgd) R.R. Steinnauer.
The Methodist Church,

Sir:-

I have the honor to report that, during my recent visit to the Saskatchewan Country, I visited the Saddle Lake Agency, and, among other matters which were brought before me, was that of the Roman Catholic Church being allowed to go upon the Saddle Lake Reserve, and erect a Church and School House, and teach. After a little parleying, I obtained the consent of Chief Pakan, and his Indians, to allow of the erection of buildings upon that part of the Saddle Lake Reserve, known as Blue Quills. Most of the followers of Blue Quill are Roman Catholics, and in order to obviate as much as possible, the ill feeling which would in all probability continue to exist, I induced the Indians of that portion of the Saddle Lake Reserve owned by Pakan and his followers to consent to move over to Blue Quill's portion, so that all those claiming adherence to that Denomination, numbering about 30 odd souls, might be together. Monsieur,

Je reçois votre lettre du 6 courant au sujet de votre "Boarding School" du Lac la Biche et aussi au sujet des enfants Calder dont deux garçons sont actuellement au Lac la Biche et qui ont déjà été le sujet de quelque correspondance. Toute justice que paraît la réclamation de votre Grandeur à propos de ces enfants je me permets de mettre les faits dans une lumière qui lui fera reconnaître, je l'espère que la conduite de M. Reed ne pouvait être autre que celle adoptée.

Au mois de Février 1873, M. Blinte, notre agent des montagnes de Paix nous suggérait après le décès de la mère des enfants Calder de faire admettre les enfants à St. Albert. Nous le permettons pourvu qu'il fut bien entendu que ce serait dans "grand", l'école de St. Albert ayant déjà atteint son nombre maximum à cette époque. M. Reed offrit cependant de les recevoir à Régina où il existait plusieurs vacances; M. Blinte répondit que les enfants étant catholiques il y aurait objection de la part des autorités à les laisser venir ici.

Vers le milieu de Mai suivant Madame Calder, la grand-mère de passage à Edmonton, fit des démarches en faveur des enfants pour les faire recevoir à Régina puisque l'orphelinat de St. Albert était plus qu'en complet. Dans cette lettre pour la première fois, nous apprîmes que la mère des enfants bien qu'ayant appartenu au traité l'avait depuis quitté et pris un "script". M. Reed pour cette raison refusa de les recevoir à l'école industrielle de Régina.

Au mois de juin 1875, nous refusâmes de payer à l'école du Lac la Biche le "grand" pour les deux Calder pour cette même raison.

Votre

His Lordship Bishop Grandin
St. Albert, Alta.

My dear Mr. Forget:

I believe it is my duty to write to you in reference to our Institution (Boarding School) of Lac la Biche. This has existed for over 40 years and upon the request of the Hon. Mr. Dewdney, it has been almost entirely remodelled in the last few years. In the course of September 1890, I made an application to the Hon. E. Dewdney for an Industrial School for the Pitt District, making an offer to move our Lac la Biche Orphanage to any locality of this District he would prefer, to which he answered: "Since you have already an Institution at Lac la Biche it would be better to have your Industrial School there than elsewhere," on the strength of which we have since expended over ten thousand dollars increasing or repairing this establishment.

Allow me to tell you, Sir, that it seems strange to me to see the unwillingness of the Indian Department to do more for establishments the cost whereof has been entirely to our charge, than for others for which it has borne the entire cost of erection. It seems that the least thing that could be done for such Institutions would be to fix no other limit to the recruiting of pupils than such as would be regulated by the needs of
the Indians. However in several instances we have, to our own cost, exceeded the number of pupils allowed, because the Indian Department endeavoured to oblige some Catholic children to be incorporated in Protestant Industrial Schools, under the pretence that the Catholic ones had their full number. We might have overlooked this, if in those Protestant Institutions the faith of our children were unmolested; but notwithstanding the conditions of the Treaty in regard to religious belief, notwithstanding formal promises from Sir John A. Macdonald and Hon. E. Dewdney, promises which are written and printed and of which neither you nor Mr. Reed are unaware, if parents are not forced to change their belief, poor little children are. We are consequently in the necessity of exceeding the limits and it would be but justice that account be taken of it.

Some years ago there was on the Ermineskin Reserve an Indian woman with three children. She took some steps towards having them admitted in our St. Albert Institution, where at the time the allowed number of pupils had been exceeded. If my information is correct, and I believe it is, Mr. H. Reed caused her to be offered that she might send her children to Regina where there was no lack of room. This poor woman, notwithstanding her past disorderly life, such a life very likely caused by her poverty, would not consent to expose her children to the danger of losing the faith in which they had been baptized. As there was room at Lake la Biche, I sent the two little boys there and placed
placed the little girl in a different Mission, for a time, on account of the difficulties of the journey.

I wonder why the Department has never consented to pay the grant for these children who are educated at Lake la Biche. It is said, I hear, that they are not Indian, the father being a civilized half-breed. Let it be, but were they not under the Department's charge when we admitted them? And if the mother had consented to have them sent to Regina, wouldn't the Department have paid a grant for them? Surely, you will not deny this. I refrain from writing all that indignation inspires me with on this subject; this is for later on if I am forced to it. But another reason is given; the Department is not willing to pay for these children as it would be indirectly favouring immorality. Worthy scruples indeed, but it should have been felt earlier. You allow a poor Indian woman to live in a disorderly way and you take no steps either with her or with the wretch who abuses her, to put an end to it. And when abandoned by her pseudo husband, this dishonoured woman returns to the reserve, you are obliged to support her and her children. I am in doubt even whether any reproof has been given her for her past conduct. Us, we admit them to give them a Christian education and it is then that your scruples begin to show. Would it have been the same if the mother consented to let them go to Regina. As for me, seeing what is going on, I am inclined to think that I am the culprit, not the mother, who likely would have finally consented to let the children go to Regina.
Regina if I had not found room for them in some of our Institutions.

I therefore claim, according to strict justice, a complete payment for these children, and I shall then see that the little girl be with her brothers at Lake la Biche. Moreover I claim that this Institution be authorized to admit at least 70 pupils, and more if necessary. It is awkward to be in the necessity to refuse many Indians who to-day seem to understand the benefit of education.

I close this too long letter with the prayer that you take this request into consideration. Grant, for the present at least, 30 pupils for the Lake la Biche Boarding School and that these three illegitimate Calder children be taken on the same footing as the others.

Believe, Dear Sir, yours faithfully,

(Sgd) X Vital J. Bishop of St. Albert,

O. M. I.

I have not thought advisable to send the girl there, when I learnt that the Department was unwilling to do anything for these children, fearing to overburthen the Institution. The father of these children is named Antoine Calder, son of William Calder, who many years ago had been employed by the Hudson's Bay

To the Acting Superintendent General of Indian Affairs.

Re request for assistance made by Indians at Lac la Biche, through Reverend Father Grondin.

---

With reference to letter on attached file, from Rev. Father Grondin, the undersigned begs to state that the Indians referred to have not been wilfully neglected but treated on a well defined policy which is to leave hunting Indians in outlying districts to their own resources, until the failure of the hunt may convince them of the necessity for settling down and learning to farm; because, if persuaded to do so before having been so convinced, it is found that they go off on the hunt and neglect their farming at the most important seasons, and yet depend on their farms sufficiently to create a certain indifference with regard to energetically prosecuting the hunt, and then endeavour to hold the Department responsible and throw themselves upon it.

As the Indians decide to turn to agriculture, the undersigned would recommend that, in accordance with the policy which has proved so successful at Onion Lake and other points, instead of giving them a separate reserve, involving sooner or later, the provision of a Farming Instructor, and a not inconsiderable expenditure in other ways, they be made to join the reserve at Saddle Lake, where all the machinery for their instruction and supervision exists and where they would benefit by the help and example of others who have already become farmers. There is
a band there of their co-religionists, and some land might be added to the reserve if the owners demand it in consideration of the addition to their numbers.

It has not been considered inconsistent with the policy defined to send the Indians some relief when emergency has arisen, and such has been done; but to give such assistance as now asked for would only retard the eventual settlement of the Indians, and do more harm than good.

In any case, Lac la Biche is not a good locality for the Indians, surrounded as it is by Half Breeds who can hardly eke out an existence. As to cattle, such Indians do not understand their care, and soon tire of them, and either let them starve, or kill and eat them.

The fact that these Indians forfeited Treaty rights by disloyalty during the Rebellion exonerates the Department from any charge of breaking faith with them in carrying out a policy which experience teaches to be in their own as well as the Department's best interests; and as a matter of fact the Treaty stipulation relative to choice of reserves was "That the Chief Superintendent of Indian Affairs shall depute and send a suitable person to determine and set apart the reserves for each band, after consulting with the Indians thereof as to the locality which may be found to be most suitable for them."

(sgd) Hayter Reed.

Sir,

I have the honour to inform you that Harriet Sinclair pupil No.036, aged 8 years, of the Blue Quill Boarding School is suffering from very sore eyes and requires constant medical treatment which the situation of the Blue Quill's Reserve renders impossible, the nearest Doctor being at Fort Saskatchewan 75 miles distant.

The case is such a serious one that I would ask for permission to send the little girl to the Edmonton hospital where she would be well treated. The hospital charges used to be and so far as I know still are $1.00 per day, board, care and medicine, and Dr. Harrison, medical attendant for the Edmonton Agency would no doubt give his services at the usual rate to the Department, of $1.00 per visit.

It would be useless, so far as the child is concerned, to send her home, there she would have no attention, her mother is dead and her father is a thriftless cripple. The Rev. Principal, Father Grandin, agrees with me that the only way to cure the child is to send her to the hospital. I therefore hope you will kindly grant my request and send me a reply at your earliest convenience.

Sir:

In compliance with your instructions, I beg to inform you that I held a meeting of the Indians belonging to the Saddle Lake Band 125 and Blue Quill's Band 127, for the purpose of signing the enclosed agreement.

The Indians of Saddle Lake Band would not consent to admit Blue Quill's Band to share their rights and interests in the reserve, unless I would promise them that the Blue Quill Boarding School etc., would not at any time be moved to the Saddle Lake side of the reserve.

I informed them that I did not think the Department had any intention of moving the Blue Quill Boarding School from the present site.

After carefully explaining matters to them, they signed the agreement under the following condition, that the Department would not allow the Blue Quill Boarding School and Mission to be moved to the Saddle Lake side of the reserve.

I would suggest that the Department write, to this effect so that the Indians may be satisfied, and that the old agreement stand, viz., that the Blue Quill Boarding School and Mission remain at its present site on the west side of the reserve, or on what has been known as Blue Quill's Reserve.

I had all the Indians who signed the first agreement that were alive, or willing, sign first then Blue Quill and his followers signed after them.

Trusting the same is satisfactory,

I am, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir,

A few months ago I have made an application to the Department of Public Works to get a permit to cut 50,000 feet of timber to be used in the construction of an addition to the Blue Quills Boarding School, the work having been authorized by the Indian Commissioner David Laird.

There was a saw-mill not far from here last winter and I was anxious not to miss the chance I had to get the lumber there at a reasonable price. I gave the contract to Henri Guibert Carpenter, and his men waited for the permit about four weeks. After that they began to cut the logs and saw the lumber, as no one of us doubted the permit was not granted, the Department itself having authorized the work!
But when the lumber were cut and all carried near the School instead of a permit I was not a little amazed in receiving a letter from the Indian Commissioner (to whom I had sent the bill) saying that a mistake had been made and that the $600 in fact had been voted not for us but for the Pegau Reserve.

However he recommended the affair at Ottawa, and we received the $600 not to pay the building which is not yet erected, but to pay the lumber which is cut and freighted.

We thought we were justified to cut the lumber before we got the permit as we could not suppose it would be refused or delayed any longer, as according to the timber regulations we had a right to a free permit.

I hope these explanations will give you satisfaction.

I have the honor to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Leon Butler

Very Honourable Sir,

I think it is my duty to write you about a class of children living on this Reserve, and I wish you will be interested in their fate. I mean those illegitimate children, whose mother is of Indian blood, and whose father is some White Man. The father does not acknowledge the child, and so the Mother alone incumbs the duty to feed, educate and instruct the child. She being an Indian Woman living on the Reserve, necessarily the child himself will be brought up among Indians. All his life he will be considered and will consider himself an Indian. He will only feel at home on the Reserve, where he knows all his relatives. He too, would never be willing to acknowledge his father, and to stay with him.

Are not these children unfortunate enough, and are we to make their condition worse yet, in refusing them the admission to the only School at hand, that is the Indian Boarding School. Are those children condemned to remain without any Education at all?

Hitherto the Indian Department has it always considered its duty to admit such children in the Boarding schools, and such policy was right and fair.

I write to you personally, very Honourable Sir, knowing enough the humanity of your sentiments and ideas, to believe that you will design interest yourself in behalf of these unfortunate children, so much so as their number is very limited.

I have the honor to be, Sir, your obedient servant,
Ottawa, April 22nd., 1910.

Reverend Sir,

In reply to your letter of the 8th. of April addressed to the Honourable the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs, I have to inform you that it is not the intention of this Department to alter its policy as regards the admission to residential schools of children who have Indian blood, whether they be legitimate or illegitimate. The Department will, however, insist on all the conventions being observed in these matters and no children can be admitted until after a careful medical examination, and a recommendation and full statement of the facts from the Agent.

Your obedient servant,

Secretary.

Re. Mr. Brighteyes Complaints.

1. Blue Quill School's Boarders have 3 full meals per day besides lunch at 3:30 P.M. They have oatmeal with milk at breakfast (or molasses for a short time during winter when we get short of milk.) But we don't think advisable to give sugar at every meal. Refits have bread & butter or butter in summer beside oatmeal & milk. They are also helped with tea.

2. It is absolutely false that Refits are given at breakfast the same food from the Sisters' table. 1st because the Sisters, the staff, the Principal and the children have their meal at the same time (7 A.M.) 2nd Because scraps from the Sisters would hardly be sufficient to feed 45 Boarders with a very extraordinary good appetite.

3. Noon Meal - Children have soup, meat, potatoes & other vegetables, tea & milk every day but Fridays. It is utterly false they are fed of the refuse from the Sisters' table.

4. I must state once for all that the meat is of the same animals we are helped with (we the staff) and the bread is absolutely the same as the one on the Sisters' and the Fathers' table, being of the 1st Quality of Strong Bakers' Flour. We have no other in this establishment.

5. Have meat, vegetables at supper, rice & beans and occasionally fruits at noon evening, pudding or some kind of cake &c.
6) Any body visiting the school can judge by himself of
the splendid health the children are enjoying in spite of
the diseases they have inherited from their parents.

7) Would like to know if there was ever a single Indian
on this P.Q. Reserve who has been qualified to judge
of the competency of the Sisters as teachers. Will state
of the two Sisters teaching at school, one is Irish, com-
pletely devoid of English accent, never speaks a word
of French to the pupils. The other is of Canadian
extraction, but, according to all even the Indians
themselves is the best teacher they ever had.

8) In regard to Clothing I will express the wish that in this
afternoon the pupils be more modest and be always active
as they are just now. It is absolutely false that they
work outside in the winter without mittens and, I am sure,
there is not a single Indian on the settlement who ever
spent $10 yearly for extras in favor of their children.
The Sisters have been very lenient in correcting
offenses and if parents were not their own children's
more advisers, they would save the staff a good deal
of trouble & worry.

Sir,

About 14 months ago I was instructed to investigate a number of complaints made by Indians against the staff of the Blue Quills boarding school. The letter was placed on the wrong file, evidently, for I'm unable to place my hands on it as I expected for the purpose of quoting No. and date.

While at Saddle Lake Agency I learned that Peter Bright Eyes was the chief complainant and I called him to make specific charges.

Charge 1. Pupils get for breakfast, so they say, "The leave over from the sisters table, such as bread made into soup with small pieces of meat therein and hot water, bread, butter and either milk or tea without any sugar in the tea. Complainant thought should have porridge with milk and sugar, or meat, in addition to bread and butter and tea with sugar.

Charge 2. Lunch about the same as breakfast and no sugar in the tea. Complainant thought children should have soup, meat and potatoes or other vegetables, bread and butter and tea with sugar therein.

Charge 3. Stated got principally the left over from the sisters table for supper and bread and butter. The tea, as usual, no sugar therein. Entertained the view that the children should get for supper: bread and butter, fruit of some sort, such as dried or evaporated apples, rhubarb in season or boiled rice with milk or sugar thereon.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
Charge 4. Complainant stated that "too much French spoken by the staff and one teacher spoke with a strong French accent and this objectionable to him when he desires the children to talk and understand English".

Charge 5. "Pupils too poorly clothed and that he usually expends about $10.00 annually on clothing for his boy now in that school."

Charge 6. "Thinks too severe punishment inflicted, does not object to light punishment if pupils deserve it"

"Peter Bright Eyes" further stated that there were three new sisters since the complaint made and with the exception of one sister they were a great improvement over those transferred, that there has been a good deal of improvement in the management within the last year but still room for improvement.

I shall attach herewith the Rev'd. Father Husson's answers to the charges made and I desire to say that the teacher referred to as having a strong French accent in her speech was absent and that I'm unable, therefor, to state whether "Bright Eyes" complaint is reasonable or otherwise.

I examined a lot of bread newly taken from the oven. It was light, sweet and well baked. Evidently a good grade of flour is purchased, better than some lots I have seen delivered under contract to the Department and for issue to the Indians and to the officers of the Department.

Personally I am not in sympathy with educating children to demand sugar in and on every thing set before them to eat. Well cooked porridge with good milk is sufficiently good for me and think it should be for all children. I further think that schools should not encourage the high cost
cost of living. Plain substantial well cooked food and chiefly of such products as will be within their reach, if they work, in after life. Most Indians are in a position to keep a cow and cultivate a garden and I prefer to know that the children are supplied with an abundance of good milk and vegetables to sugar on porridge and in tea.

My impression is that the Saddle Lake Indians have, not now at least, many reasons for complaining regarding the treatment within the Blue Quill's school.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir,

A few days ago three Indians from Saddle Lake Reserve came all the way from there to see me in St. Albert. They were:

1. Thomas (Shokohus) Head chief - Protestant
2. Moses (Ayawake) Counsellor - Catholic
3. Peter Bright Eyes - Catholic

They wanted to see me about the two ordered petitions:

1. One petition referring to the transformation of the Roman Catholic Boarding School at Blue Quills' Band into a Roman Catholic Industrial school; the other
2. Petition referring to a project of handing to Chief Pakan of White Earth Lake Reserve, a certain tract of the Saddle Lake Reserve.

I advised them to go and treat both questions, and especially the latter one, with the Indian agent on the Reserve, and then I would be ready to give them any assistance needed.

I am informed that the agent refused to forward their petitions to the Indian Department.

Consequently, I believe that I may be allowed to give through your good offices, some explanations on both questions, to the Indian Department.

1st question: Transformation of the Roman Catholic Boarding School into an Industrial school. I may say that this is desirable, as the Indians object always to have their children transferred to a far away normal school, and the present building is not large enough to accommodate the number of children who could be admitted into it, so that the request of the Indians is perfectly justified.

I may add that when the Department puts up a new enlarged building, we will be in a position to take charge of said school, and the community of Saddle
already in charge of the Boarding school, will provide the necessary staff for the new institution, viz., masters for a few ladies, besides the teaching staff.

3rd question: Project of handing to chief Pakan a certain tract of the Reserve.

Although I do not like, in a general way, to interfere in purely secular matters, yet in this particular case, I think I can, at least, explain the reasons of the objection to the project, coming from both sides, Protestant as well as Catholic.

Some arrangement has been entered into, several years ago, to the effect that the Indians from White Fish Lake Reserve and other Reserves, of the same agency, could come and locate on the Saddle Lake Reserve, and vice versa. Indians from Saddle Lake could go and locate on the other Reserve. Yet it must be noted that this arrangement had been taken all in favour of the benefit of the other Reserve, as there is not the smallest inducement for Indians of Saddle Lake to quit, and go elsewhere.

Work, partly expensive, has been done on the Saddle Lake Reserve, as the fencing in all round of the Reserve, to which Chief Pakan have never contributed. The only assistance received, and contributed personally by three or four Indians, of the other Reserves, does not amount to more than £20.

The Indians of Saddle Lake Reserve are perfectly satisfied to stand by the arrangement, leaving the Reserve undivided. But now it is proposed that the Reserve be divided and that a tract from it be handed to Chief Pakan and his band, in separate ownership. This they object to.

It is no secret that Mr. Inspector Marsh has been trying to get the Indians' consent, for the relinquishing of part of the Reserve. The impression is that, if a certain tract of the Reserve is made out to Chief Pakan, he will take it immediately and get all the profit of the sale for himself and his band.

The rest of the Reserve, in a general way, seem to be opposed to the sale of part of the Reserve, or at any rate, if the sale is to take place, we want the consent of the majority of the Band; they want to share in the profits.

I hope that these explanations will be taken in good part, and are professed only with the view of securing equal justice to all.

Yours very sincerely,

[Signature]

P.S. I hope I may depend on your kindness to communicate these remarks to Hon. the Superintendent-General, if necessary, before withdrawing your attention.

10.- The main building was generally overhauled this year and some additions made. Water has been conveyed from the well through a pipe to a tank in the attic and cess pit connected with the lavatories, etc. The work has not yet been completed and in my opinion when it is completed according to present plans, will be lacking in the particulars specified under sections 2, 5, 6 to place it in Class "A", as defined on pages 5 and 6 of the agreement relating to schools. It is intended to add some modern lighting system. My impression is that more improvements are under consideration and that they will be carried out as soon as funds are available to meet the cost. The greatest difficulty now will be to get the basement full and to conform to the requirements.

The church authorities own the buildings in connection with this institution, so it has been decided. They are now at work on improvements and with a view of placing it under Class "A". An "Ideal" steam heater has been set in the basement, radiators placed in all rooms, 5 bath tubs and 5 closets, 6 wash basins and 2 sinks are installed. A water tank, capacity about 500 gallons, placed in the attic and hot and cold water will shortly be provided for use in the kitchen in connection with the baths and wash basins.

The site was not well chosen for such an institution. There is not sufficient fall of land from the main building to ensure good drainage and at a nominal cost. A sewer pipe is to be carried to an unused well and I presume when the cess pit (old well) gets full it must be pumped out and transported away. There is a stone and mortar wall foundation, but the basement is not a "full one", neither has the portion excavated a cement concrete floor. About the only method of procedure, in my opinion, to get this institution in Class "A", as defined in the memorandum of agreement, page 6 of correspondence and agreement record, was to have jacked up the building about 3', excavated to a depth of about 6' under the entire building, placed new foundation walls throughout with windows therein and a floor throughout of cement concrete. The additional 3' elevation would have provided a well lighted basement, greater fall for the sewer, etc. Then additional dormitory space for boys would be demanded. The ceilings fortunately on the two floors are high and these ceilings have been lined with dressed matched lumber and walls have either been painted or it is still to be done. It is intended too, to place new flooring (laminate) throughout the first floor. The work is not completed at present. It is expected that it will be during June and that after the summer vacation it will be in shape to ask for the grant to be increased from $100.00 to $125.00 per capita. Oil and lamps supply the required light.

Memorandum,

Mr. Scott.

The Saddle Lake boarding school authorities have, during the past few years, made extensive improvements to their building and equipment that these might be registered in the A Class. Steam heating and electric lighting systems have been installed, also sanitary plumbing and drainage, with hot and cold water to the fixtures there, basement excavated and foundation walls placed under the building.

It is doubtful, however, if the basement will prove satisfactory unless the building is raised to permit of proper lighting and excavation and concrete flooring, as, without this, it could scarcely be termed light and airy. Answering your letter of September 6th, I have the honour to state that the improvements to the Blue Quill's boarding school, with a view of getting it placed in the "A" class of Indian educational institutions, are still incomplete. I have made up a pencil sketch, and shall enclose it herewith, showing the dimensions of main building and annexes thereto, as you requested me to do.

The ground on which the main building is located is not as high as it should be and the mistake that was made at the outset, when starting to remodel it, about 2 years ago, was not to have raised it about 2' and in that way partially, at least, overcome the flatness of land. The steam heating plant and the sewerage were installed about 2 years ago and it would be more expensive and difficult to raise the main building and the annexes at this late date. and better facilities provided for the drainage to the cess pit, etc.

Dear Mr. Scott:

Inspector Murison, who has recently returned from the Saddle Lake Agency, informed me that within the last two weeks some seventeen children have been admitted to the Blue Quills Boarding School on the Saddle Lake Agency. The Sisters in charge of course cannot begin to carry on the work and feed the additional number of children that have recently been admitted, although they have the accommodation I am told.

I am informed that this Institution is doing good work, and I think, if it is at all possible, we should do what we can to assist them in carrying the work through; especially when it is so hard to make ends meet owing to the high cost of living. MEMORANDUM.

Mr. Scott,

Mr. Commissioner Graham requests that provision be made for an additional number of pupils at the Blue Quills Boarding School. He states that Inspector Murison, who recently returned from the Saddle Lake Agency, informed him that seventeen children have been admitted from the Beaver Lake Band, which is some hundred of miles north of Saddle Lake Agency.

The grant at present allowed is for 45 pupils at $145.00 per capita, the school being graded as Class "A" since January 1st, 1919. During the year 1918 extensive repairs were made to the school building. Excavations were made under the main building and a concrete basement put in. A steam heating plant and a sewage system were installed and an isolation hospital fitted up in the old laundry building and the walls and floors of the main building renovated. The floor space in the dormitories was not enlarged and in a memorandum hereunder from Mr. Ogilvie, the Architect, he stated the accommodation in the boys' dormitory to be suitable for 19 boys and in the girls for 23, equal to 42 pupils; and, as the floor space is ample, one or two additional pupils might be allowed in excess, thus providing for the 45 pupils for which the grant is authorized.

The Commissioner states that he has been told that the school has accommodation for the 17 extra pupils who have recently been admitted and that the Sisters in charge cannot begin to carry on the work and feed this additional number of children without receiving a grant therefor. The December quarter return has not yet been received, but there were 42 children on the roll at the end of September.

If it is intended to provide for the children recently brought into the school it would require a grant for at least an additional 15 pupils. It will, no doubt, be possible to provide for that number from the general appropriation for Indian Education and I shall be pleased to have your decision as to whether
whether the request of the Commissioner be complied with and an additional pupilage be provided. It would require a total of $2,175.00 to provide a yearly per capita grant for 15 extra pupils at the same rate as is allowed for the other 45 pupils already provided for. If the grant for the above extra number is approved, I would recommend that it date from January 1st, last.

It might be well, however, to first ascertain definitely the number of children the school can accommodate, taking into account the requirements as to air space in the dormitories and class-room. Mr. Ogilvie's report on the matter is turned out hereunder, and, as far as I am aware, no additions have since been added to the buildings.

Extract from Mr. Inspector Murison's report on the Saddle Lake Agency, Regina, Sask., December 24, 1920.

BLUE JAYLING BOARDING SCHOOL

The main building is a frame three story structure with a full sized basement. It is steam heated and has a Delco lighting plant installed which was temporarily out of use at the time of my visit owing to the batteries being burned out. The basement has a high ceiling and cement floor and is equipped as a wash room. Water is pumped into a storage tank and from there is piped through the building for fire protection and all other requirements. Outside stairways from each floor are provided as fire escapes.

There are two dormitories for the girls and one for the boys. Each bed is provided with a comfortable mattress. There is also an infirmary for the isolation of the sick. There are two classrooms and the usual accommodation found in a school of this class. Everything was scrupulously clean. The pupils had a clean and health appearance.

The school provides accommodation for 45 pupils and a staff of 10. Their stables were burned down a year ago and have been replaced at a cost of $4,000.00 by a large barn 36' x 90' with a large loft for storing feed. This building adds to the appearance of the place. The buildings and grounds are neatly fenced in and present a well kept appearance.

There is only sufficient land in connection with the school to permit them to crop 15 acres. The sisters, however, this season rented 50 acres from the Indians and seeded 65 acres from which they threshed 1500 bushels of oats. Their garden yielded 500 bushels of potatoes and sufficient vegetables for the use of the school.

Their live stock consists of 48 cattle, 20 pigs and 75 poultry. They milk 10 cows in summer and 4 during the winter months. The boys assist with the farm work. The girls are taught butter making, breadmaking, knitting and mending clothes. I saw some very fine knitting and needle work done by the pupils of this school.

There are 44 pupils enrolled, 16 boys and 28 girls. Their class standing is as follows:

Sir:

I have to acknowledge receipt of your telegram of yesterday, referring to the criminal proceedings against the alleged seducer of Mary Rose, pupil of the Saddle Lake Indian Boarding School. I have to confirm my telegram of this date, as follows:

"Department does not provide for defense of Indians except when charged with murder. Writing."

I have referred to official communication of December 10th, last, concerning this matter, and I notice that, before legal proceedings were initiated by the Department, more information was requested. I might add that to date no information has been received from you.

The Department's policy, concerning the defense of Indians charged under the Criminal Code, is that no action will be taken unless the defendant is in danger of the death penalty. While Section 299 of the Criminal Code referring to rape provides for the death penalty, yet such punishment is never imposed in Canadian courts of today. Further, I might add, for your information, that when the defendant in a murder charge is able to bear the expense, the Department does not interfere.

The Department will be pleased to learn who laid the information in connection with this case at Saddle Lake, and we would like to be informed as to the outcome of the trial.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Aest. Deputy and Secretary.

Sir,

I have the honour to acknowledge the receipt of your letter No. 407/22 A of the 14th inst. in regard to Mary Rose Makokis, a pupil of the Sacred Heart Boarding School.

Mary Rose told Miss Johnston that William John Doghead, a young man of 32 years of age, was responsible for her condition. On enquiry, Mary Rose told me that William John wanted to marry her, but that her father objected. Later, I sent for William John, and he stated that at treaty time in July last, he wanted to marry Mary Rose, but now, owing to her present condition, he refused, as he declared that he had had nothing to do with her.

I explained to him the seriousness of the charge under section 301 of the Criminal Code, and told him of the penalty if he was convicted. He still maintained his innocence, and elected to stand trial rather than marry her.

Accordingly on December 10th, he was arraigned before Mr. D. McEachern, J. P., of Ashmont, and the evidence of Mary Rose was deemed sufficient by the Justice of the Peace to commit him for trial at the next court of competent jurisdiction.

William John was taken into custody and he will probably be brought up for trial at the next sitting of the District Court, which I understand will be held at St. Paul during the early part of February.

I had first thought of referring the matter to you, but lately considered that it would come directly under my administration.

Dear Mr. Scott:

Upon my return from my Western trip, last September, I took up with you personally an important question relative to the Sisters of Blue Quills Indian Boarding School.

This school is under the direction of the Grey Nuns of Montreal and an Oblate Father is the nominal Principal. The time seems to have come when the Sisters can no longer assume the responsibility of the School for reasons, some personal to them, some relating to the greater good of the Indian work in the District.

I made a special trip to Montreal to consult with the Very Reverend Mother General in the matter and she proved more than earnest for a change in the direction of the Institution. The following are some of the points brought in the discussion:

1o. - The present condition of the buildings which would necessitate a complete overhauling and in fact would warrant the construction of a new school;

2o. - The enormous expenses made by the Sisters for the last five years amounting to $21,000.00 over the per capita grant, the latter being entirely spent for the school. A debt of over $8000.00 is still left and proves a heavy burden for the Sisters;

3o. - The reluctance or rather the impossibility for the Sister to keep boys over 12 or 13 years;

4o. - The awkward position of the Principal who though seemingly vested with responsibility before the Department is only a salaried official at
School, with no responsibility nor authority whatever in the management of it.

I have also fully discussed this matter by correspondence with Very Reverend Father Blanchin, C.S.S., Provincial of the Oblates and with his permission and that of Very Reverend Mother Dugas, Mother General of the Grey Nuns of Montreal, I take the liberty of stating the following:

10. - It is of self-evidence that Blue Quills school must be rebuilt before long but at the proximity of a railway station;

So. - The present policy of discharging boys at 14 years old must be brought to an end on account of the moral difficulties and also on account of the impossibility for these boys to be trained in farming work.

So. - The school should be placed under the authority of the Oblate Fathers but the latter would not consider such a proposition unless:

a) the present debt is entirely wiped off;
b) the Government agrees to keep the school in a fair state of repair;
c) a promise is made by the Government to rebuild the school near a railway station in a very near future.

Regarding the debt of $3000.00 above referred to, I would suggest that the Department assume it and even add to that amount a gratuity to the Sisters who have worked so many years without any salary and who also spent so much money on the building and land.

I leave all the above facts, considerations and requests to your appreciation with the hope that a favourable decision will be reached. In such a case I would place before you the official propositions of Very Rev. Mother Dugas and Very Rev. Father Blanchin, C.S.S.

Respectfully yours,

Honorable Sir:

I have the honor hereby to apply to the Indian Department regarding the urgent necessity of having for this school some larger and modern buildings. Out of many grounds supporting my humble request, I beg to state the following:

1st. According to our last quarter report ending June 30th, there are 17 pupils 12 years old, which number if taken as an average every year, would make a total of 200 pupils between 6 and 18 years of age. (viz. 17 x 12 = 204).

2nd. As there are in said report, only 13 pupils under 10 years old, this means that though there are on this Reserve many other young children of school age, we do not recruit them, our school since a few years being crowded to its full capacity.

3rd. On our reports you may notice, that in the past we did not keep the boys in school after being 12 years old. Now, realizing that your plan of keeping the boys in school till 18 years old in order that they may be trained in practical work, as it is done in Duck Lake School, is very much desirable, for the future welfare of our Indians, we intend to keep them also till that age. Hence the urgent necessity of having a large and modern school connected with a well equipped and extensive farm.

4th. As your refusal to put an addition to our actual building, considered unworthy to be enlarged, gives us an opportunity to make up our mind regarding the advisability of changing its site. We consider that a school site 10 miles distant from a railway station is very inconvenient and very expensive; and therefore, after having inspected many possible locations, I found that the best suitable site would be within about one mile east of St. Paul de Retin Station, which is only 2 miles east of the Eastern boundary of this Reserve. Should this site be accepted, our school being not far from this Reserve will become more central for two other ones, that is, Long Lake and Cold Lake Reserves, the latter is entirely Catholic, and up to the
present time no child attends any Boarding School. So we may expect to get very pupils from there.

Therefore I hope that if you take this plan into consideration, we will be granted in a near future, a modern school for about 200 pupils.

Hoping to receive a favorable reply,

I have the honor to be,

Honorable Sir,

Your humble Servant,

V. Gabillon acting principal

There is a matter which requires a special report from me. I refer to the school requirements for the Indians of this Agency and part of the Onion Lake Agency, viz.: Keeweenaw Reserve. In my opinion, the question of building a school on the Saddle Lake Agency should not be considered. The school should be built at St. Paul de Metis, and should be sufficiently large to accommodate not only the children of the Saddle Lake Reserve, but of Cold Lake and Keecheewins reserves as well. Of course, if this scheme is carried out, and I think it should be, the Department should insist on closing up the day schools. In my opinion, the operating of these schools is only a useless waste of money, for which we are getting no value.

Most Reverend Sir,

The Honourable the Superintendent General has favoured me with a copy of the letter he wrote Your Grace on November 28th with reference to the provision of boarding school buildings in your archdiocese.

I am today instructing our chief officer at Regina to have an examination and valuation made of the property at Hobbsma known as the Ermineskin's Boarding School. We have during the past few years purchased institutions from the Oblate Order, but these buildings have been well adapted to the needs of such institutions as now recognized, and a reasonable amount has been paid for them, even less than their appraised value, and Parliament has provided the money for the purchase. The examination and valuation which I am ordering now is merely a preliminary step, and the question will be very carefully and sympathetically considered.

With reference to the establishment of a boarding school at Saddle Lake, Mr. Graham has already made recommendation that a school for this district should be established at or in the vicinity of St. Paul de Metis; an institution at this point would, he thinks, serve the Roman Catholic Indians of Cold Lake, Saddle Lake and Kesheewin reserves. Sir,— 

I beg to inform you that the school authorities at the Blue Quill's Residential School have today made the request that they be granted permission to extend the annual Summer holidays from July 5th to August 25th instead of July 5th to August 18th as at first arranged. The reason given is that as there has been a good deal of sickness on the reserves during the month of July, and as several cases of measles were reported, some of the children would probably carry the disease to the school if taken in too soon and that an epidemic in the institution would probably follow. By extending the holiday period to the 25th August, they consider that there would be less danger of contagion from those who may have been in contact with persons affected.

In view of the fact that parents or other relatives of a few of the children of this school have had measles, and in two or three cases, typhoid fever, I am of the opinion that it might be advisable to extend the holiday period to the date suggested. If this meets with the approval of the Department, I would be glad to have notice to that effect by wire in order that the parents may be notified in time as to change of date.

Your obedient servant,

Sir,

With reference to the remarks in my report for the month of December, concerning the matter of certain girls running away from school, I beg to submit the following:

On the 29th December, Rev. Father Gabillon, Principal of the Blue Quill's Residential school, advised me that three of the girls were absent and asked if I would look into the matter. I accordingly went to the school in the afternoon and on my arrival, was informed that the girls had just been brought in. They were Veronica Memmcock, age 17 years, Angela Houle, age 16 years and Celestine Brightsyte, age 15 years.

On making enquiries, I found that the girls had been out all night with several young Indians. A young man, Maxime Houle, had on the Sunday previous, asked the girls to arrange to run away on Tuesday evening. He had evidently arranged to have two other boys with him but from what I could gather there were from two to six boys out with the girls during the night. The following names of Indian boys were given me by the girls,- Maxime Houle, Leo Gladu, Norrie Delver, Isaac Sampson, Johnnie Cryer and Morria Cardinal. From information given me at the school, it would appear that one or two of these boys have been the source of considerable trouble at the institution on previous occasions.

A suggestion was made that Veronica Memmcock, who apparently acted as leader of the trio, might be discharged at once and allowed to marry Norrie Delver with whom she was with. I advised strongly against adopting this procedure at the present time and suggested that the girl be kept in school for another two or three months at least. I was of the opinion that if Veronica was discharged immediately on account of her escapade, some of the older girls would be inclined to follow her example whenever they wished for an excuse to leave school. In any case, Norrie Delver is still under 16 years.

I should be glad to have your instructions and advice in the matter.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

W. M. Graham Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
Regina, Sask.,

Dear Mr. Graham:

I beg to report that I visited the Blue Quill Residential School on March 17th last, and made a general inspection of that institution. There are 69 pupils enrolled; 3 were absent on account of sickness on the date of my visit. There are two class rooms provided. The children were assembled and I noted their appearance and made a brief examination. I noted an improvement in the pronunciation of English. There has been a change in the teaching staff since my last visit a year ago. The pupils presented a clean and healthy appearance. There has been very little sickness among them during the past year. They were warmly dressed and their appearance is an indication that they are receiving ample nourishing food.

The dormitories I found well aired and quite ample for the present enrollment. Authority has been granted for the admission of an additional 10 pupils, and sleeping accommodation for that number of the larger boys is being provided in one of the outbuildings, with a Lay Brother in charge. I examined this new dormitory and would report that it is quite adequate in size to accommodate the extra pupilage authorized and quite suitable for the purpose.

The school building is kept in a scrupulously clean condition. This is an old building, but the interior

W. M. Graham, Esq.,

Inspector Murison's report on school, Saddle Lake Agency.

The interior is kept in a very creditable manner. A Delco plant provides the lighting facilities. Their laundry machinery is operated with a separate gas engine. The exterior of the building is badly in need of a coat of paint.

They operate a farm at this school. The crop last year consisted of 100 acres of grain and they will seed 125 acres this year. Their last season's crop was a failure owing to dry weather and did not provide their flour requirements. They have 6 acres for roots and vegetables, the yield from which was poor last year.

Their stock consists of 70 head of cattle, 10 work horses, 2 colts and 45 hogs, and they have over 100 poultry. They milk from 15 to 20 cows, but at the time of my visit, they were only milking 2. This, however, would only be for a very short period. The stock and poultry produces their requirements for meat, butter and eggs. They derive real benefit from the produce of their farm and stock.

This school is under the auspices of the Roman Catholic Church. The Rev. V. Gabillion, O.M.I., is Principal. The Rev. Sister Courneyer of the Order of Grey Nuns, is the business manager. She is assisted by a staff of six Sisters, which includes a trained nurse, 2 teachers, a cook, laundress and seamstress, all of whom appear to be quite capable in their own departments. The girls are taught knitting and sewing, and practically all the clothing of the pupils is made by the girls under the supervision of a sister. They had quite a lot of work under way at the time of my visit and the quality of the work looked excellent to me and reflects credit on their teacher.

Sir:-

On the 4th September I received a telegram from Mr. W. H. Gullion, Indian Agent at Saddle Lake, stating that three boys, pupils at the Blue Quill's Boarding School, had attempted to burn down the school and suggesting their transfer to the St. Albert School. I wired stating that, if they would be accepted at the latter institution, the transfer might be arranged. I have now received a letter from the Agent stating that he communicated with the authorities at St. Albert and was told that they did not consider it advisable to take these boys. Later when in Edmonton on business, he visited the school and discussed the matter and was informed that, after careful consideration in view of the boys' records, they did not feel inclined to admit them.

The names of the three boys are Patrice Castor Cardinal, aged 11, Marcisse Houle, aged 11, and Charlie Gladu, aged 13. They admitted that they planned to burn the school, and apparently had intended starting the fire in the basement, but, owing to the peculiar behaviour during the afternoon, the door to the basement was locked and they had no opportunity to go down. The fire was actually started in a small compartment on the second floor underneath the stairway leading from the boys' dormitory. Papers had been used to start the fire, and it might have had a disastrous result, but for the prompt action of the sisters when the attempt had been discovered. I shall be glad if the department will suggest what action should now be taken to discipline these boys.

Sir:

I have your 407-113 of the 27th ultimo, with reference to the attempt of three pupils of the Blue Quills Indian Residential School to start a fire in the building. You ask if the Department would suggest disciplinary action. As you are, no doubt, aware, the securing of discipline is dependent upon the personal equation between child and teacher, supervisor or principal, and it is very difficult to arbitrarily fix punishments for certain offenses. If these boys were 11 to 13 years of age, then, I believe, they should have been given a good spanking as soon as they were caught. It is doubtful if corporal punishment, when removed from the time of the offense, is advisable. Perhaps the disciplining of these boys can be left for the school management. 8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupil in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. Where, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, posting it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entering the Return and is determined by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant.
