**POOR COPY**
NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days' attendance of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days present of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount of per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively; and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The term "number of days in quarter" means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Return must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days present of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average number of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper column.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by filling the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The annual per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will provision be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Return must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

**PUBLIC ARCHIVES CANADA**
NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, ruling it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Return must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, piling it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter."

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter."

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings hereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days present of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter."

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter."

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils named on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount of capital grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper column.

4. The Return must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days recorded of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly grant allowed. NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, piling it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils included in the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount of per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance during quarter" by the rate of grant per pupil per day. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN.

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Return must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the total number of days in quarter.

9. The amount of capital grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the Average attendance of pupils during quarter by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

The amount of capital grant due for quarter is determined by multiplying the "Average attendance during quarter" by the rate of the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Return must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter."

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter."

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

Mr. Philip Phelan,

Dear Sir,

I would like to inform you that the school having not received any raffia for the past two years, the pupils of the lower grades, about 75 of them, have been working with old one, for their exhibition work. However, as raffia is very hard to secure and as the cost is very high, we will be pleased to receive what you can secure.

Thanking you sincerely,

I remain,

Yours very truly,

L.C. Latour, O.M.I.
Principal.

At last, I have the pleasure to salute the rebirth of the "Moccasin Telegram"...one of my most cherished desires is fulfilled. I have long felt the need of such a journal. In fact, is not a school without a journal like a child deprived of his voice? The "moccasin Telegram" will be the voice of Blue Quills. It will be a means of communication with other schools; of sharing ideas and ideals. It will be another link added to the great chain of friendship which binds all the Indian Schools together as well as with those who show any interest in their welfare.

It is the pupils' work. This, I hope, will foster interest, ambition and co-operation among the children. It may also help them to become conscious of their stand in society which is considerably different from that of fifty years ago.

I sincerely believe that great benefits can be derived from the publication of the school newspaper, therefore I wholeheartedly encourage this enterprise.

To the pupils, I wish: "Success" and to the journal..."Long Life."

May God bless both children and readers........

Father E.Bernet Rollande, O.M.I.
The Apostolic Delegate

How glad and anxious we were when we heard that we might have a chance to see the Apostolic Delegate. We had been looking forward to the consecration of His Excellency Bishop Maurice Baudoux.

On the day came! We were to go on the highway where the Delegate was to come. We got up early Saturday morning. After school, it did not take us long to get ready. Sometimes we used to go out for dinner. The whole house, sisters and children were on the road. We waited for the Delegate to arrive at the highway. There, we lined up two boys on the left and the girls on the right. We held our breath and the flags of very bright colors. We had to wait for quite a while. Then, the car came. We did not mind; we were only thinking of the Delegate. Many cars came behind him and went in a cloud of dust. But the one we wanted to see was not there. At last, the car stopped. The Delegate himself stepped out, followed by his wife. He walked between the two rows of children. About fifty-three cars followed. It was a lovely sight. Here they were all lined up. We were very happy. We were very happy, because we had seen the representative of the Pope in our country.

Florence Lange
Grade VIII

The Bishop's Consecration

We did not see the consecration ceremony. All the sisters said mass to raise it. But many of the Sisters went and they told us about it. We were very happy to hear about it. The Bishop's consecration lasted very long but it was a nice ceremony. We are very glad because now we have a good Bishop who lives near us.

Officer Vigne
Grade IV

Benediction

On the day of the consecration of the Bishop, Father Vigne said that we would have the chance to attend the ceremony of the consecration in the church. Afterwards we had the opportunity to go to benediction. About fifteen of the big boys, seven consecrated boys, three consecrated wives, and eighteen big girls accompanied by Sister Irene and Miss Florence Lange went with me dressed by "little and "other Principal."

When we reached the church, it was already eleven o'clock. We were late. We lined up and walked in. Father Principal was leading the procession. We all looked at the Bishop's throne, because we knew that the sisters of our school had been placed on the Bishop's throne. We waited for a while and then the organ began to play. It was the first time we heard a pipe organ. Two Fathers came in evidently to give
Then the Bishop came, and we were ready to do our best. The children stood up and sang a song which started with these words: "O happy day, Heavenly Father, we come to you."

After Benediction we all came back very pleased with our visit. When we got home we went quietly so as not to wake up those who were sleeping.

We had a good time and Mr. Painter Principal was kind enough to take us to school.

Alex Janvier
Grade VII

THE SUNDAY VISIT

The Sunday following his consecration His Excellency Bishop Sheppard came to visit our school. We had been told that he was coming and we were very excited about him.

At five o'clock, all the boys and girls went out in groups to meet him. He came in through the side of the door and walked along the hall, then we saw the Bishop. He looked very tall and handsome. We sang in Gregorian Chant at our Mass.

After Mass we went to see the Bishop. He talked to the two rooms of children and went to the chapel. While he was praying there, we went into the chapel and looked at the pictures and statues.

Cherrelling Martin
Grade VII

On the following morning the Bishop said Holy Mass in our chapel. It struck me during his sermon when he looked towards the people the first time, he did not say "Gentiles Vocatus" but he said "Gentiles Vocatus."

Before Holy Communion, he gave us his ring. He looked very tall and handsome. He is also looking and very tall. I heard him say "I believe that he likes us. Anyway we always love him much."

He came to see us often as Father Strimpel would invite him to be sure that he will come often because he likes children very much especially our dear Bishop.

Arthur Eagle
Grade VII

IN MEMORIAM

Rev. Father J. Batey

Before we left for the summer holidays last June, we went to say goodbye to our dear Father Batey. We never thought that it was for the last time. He used to be our guide. To pray for him and that he could do the same for us to always turn our prayers because he was a holy man.

It certainly was a big shock for all the Trudeau parents and children. Who thought that only a few months before, could hardly believe it. In him, we had such a great friend, a kind father.

He was really devoted to the Indians as he was among them ever since he came here. He joined the Catholic Church and became a member of Holy Priesthood in 1899. He spent his first twelve years with the Cree Indians in Sagide Lake. In 1921, he was transferred to the reserve where he spent another seven years until 1928. He then went to Cold Lake where he stayed until December 14, 1935 when he came here to St. Paul. He died on July 16, 1936.

He lived here purely and quietly. He always had a kind word for us whenever we met him. He could speak five languages: French, English, German, Cree and Chipewyan.

He seemed to mean him more than anyone else, because he was the only priest who knew us.

The chief and the ex-chief came to Father Batey's funeral in St. Paul.

"He had a golden heart and for him, it was God after his Father."

Although he was not the bishop, he was our friend. We often think and talk of him. Sometimes pray for him. We feel sure that he does not forget either that and that he is with God and will continue to help us in our needs.

We hope that he will assist especially Cherrelling Martin a grade V pupil who took his place in teaching the prayers to the Chipewyan children.

Josie Henrie
Grade VIII
BACK FROM FRANCE

OUR NEW SUPERIOR

At last, our dear old Mother De Guif is back from her long sojourn abroad. She has been away among the sisters in England for a real deserved visit to her Sisters. Our dear old Mother De Guif came to Canada in 1925. She was very young then, but she has grown up to be a fine woman. She has been very busy since she came here, and she has done a lot of good work. She has been very kind to us, and we love her very much.

Our new Superior is Sister A. Cardinal. She is a very nice lady, and she will be a great help to us. We are very happy to have her as our Superior.

Sister A. Cardinal

THE ROSARY

The month of October is the month of the Holy Rosary. We please the Blessed Virgin very much by saying the Rosary. She appeared to some little children and she told them to say it often. Bernadette, the little girl who saw her, said she had seen her too. They thought she was very beautiful and they loved her very much.

Sister gave us each a pair of beads, and we were glad because we could say the Rosary every day before we went to sleep.

Caroline Cardinal
Grade IV

"Reverend rise unspoken thoughts when we pray."

More things are wrought by prayer than this world dreams of." Tennyson
EXHIBITION

No one can imagine our excitement and happiness when we heard that our school had come first at the Edmonton and Calgary Exhibition this summer.

When we came back from the holidays we all went to see our prizes and see who had the most. For the sewing only, we got forty first prizes and about twenty second. In all the school we received over a hundred prizes counting the school exhibits. This is a great joy for us.

We were glad when the exhibition money came. We all went in the girls' room. Most of the Sisters were present. Father Principal gave us the money for our prizes. On that same occasion the girls received some badges for cooking, sewing and knitting and housekeeping. They have sewed their badges on their school dresses so they could go to wear them. We hope that many more of the pupils will get some badges next year. We also hope to have many prizes at the exhibition and come first again.

Herman Cardinal
Grade V

POTATO HARVEST

In the last days of September all the boys went to pick potatoes. We left in the morning in the wagon and came back late in the afternoon. We did not pick up many pails of potatoes because the potatoes were few. Father Principal had to go and buy some at Hobson in the truck.

John Steinhauser
Grade II

EDITORIAL

The "Kocassin Telegram" was started by the Reverend Sister Catherine Couturier in 1947. She was wholeheartedly devoted to its development and progress. We may well say that her work was crowned with success.

Owing to circumstances in 1948 the publication ceased. We are now attempting to bring back to life and publish the "Kocassin Telegram." It is of course the work of the pupils who are very enthusiastic about it.

For the printing of this issue we had recourse to the charity of the Reverend Sister L'Estivier. She kind enough to make our copies on her little press. We are indeed most grateful and may she receive here our heartfelt thanks.

We hope that with the contributions of our friends and subscribers we may be able to buy a machine for the printing of the next "Kocassin Telegram."

The Editor

Brooches

Besides the girls who received badges, some have received "Brooches." They are: Catherine Joth, Annette Poitras and Doris Pinogos. These brooches were awarded for the three years of training which comprises: Cooking, Sewing, Knitting and Housekeeping.

Our sincere congratulations!

Vivian
Dear Father Rollande:

This morning I received a copy of "Moccasin Telegram". I was very delighted to know that you have created enough enthusiasm among the pupils for such a valuable enterprise. I feel that time is well spent in the preparation of such a school magazine.

I noticed that this paper was done on a gelatin duplicator. The Department has been supplying a mimeograph outfit complete with stencils, pens, ink etc., to schools who put out such a paper as its contribution to such a project.

If you are anxious to receive such a machine, it will be in order for you to prepare a requisition and submit it here.

Sincerely yours,

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Principal has stated that he would be quite willing to meet the difference in price usually allotted for this purpose and the actual cost of the machine. I am attaching a requisition for one mimeograph, preferably ditto type if possible.

It is hoped that the attached requisition will meet with your favorable consideration.

W.K. Taylor,

The Ditto original is a thin piece of paper. A carbon copy is made by placing a sheet between the typing or drawing and Ditto Direct Process Carbon Paper. The carbon comes in four colors — purple, red, green and blue. All colors may be applied to the same original and all will reproduce in one simple operation.

This makes an original, prepared in the same manner as you would write or type a letter, is ready for instant use. Just clamp it to the cylinder of the D15 machine and run your copies. If you need only a few copies, your original may be filed and re-used over and over again until all of the dye deposit is exhausted.

Dear Father Rollande:

I have a requisition for a Ditto type mimeograph duplicator for your school.

As the price of this machine has gone up considerably in the past few years, we have been attempting to get an equal machine at a lower price. We are arranging to send you a Roneo machine complete with stencils, pens, type cleaner, stylus plate and all other accessories required to operate the machine for typewritten work and hand work.

I wish you would give this machine a thorough going over and advise us whether you like the machine. You might also advise us whether there are any faults that you can find and whether you consider it easy and clean to operate. Any other features you might care to point out will be appreciated.

Trusting to hear from you first when you receive it and later when you have used it.

Yours sincerely,

I remain,

Dear Father Rollande:

FORM No. I.A. 418
Ottawa, February 19th, 1943.

Rev. L. C. Latour, O.M.I., Blue Quills Residential School, St. Paul, Alta.

With reference to your requisition dated December 31st, it is noted that you request a quantity of raffia which would cost approximately $60.00. It is doubtful if we can secure raffia at the present time but, in any event, the quantity which you request appears to be very large. Before placing the order, I would appreciate your advising me if you feel sure that the quantities requested are absolutely necessary.

The other articles on the requisition considered necessary have been ordered. It is not possible at the present time to obtain erasers, pen nibs, pencil sharpeners, and many other articles.

A number of books for supplementary reading purposes are being forwarded with the other supplies.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Blue Quill's Ind. Res. School,
St. Paul, Alta.,
February 23, 1945.

Mr. Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir,

Re : Requisition for Raffia.

I would like to inform you that the school having not received any raffia for the past two years, the pupils of the lower grades, about 75 of them, have been working with old one, for their exhibition work. The teachers have therefore requested a larger quantity, in order to use some of it at the end of this school year.

However, as raffia is very hard to secure and as the cost is very high, we will be pleased to receive what you can secure.

Thanking you sincerely,

I remain,

Yours very truly,

L.C. Letour, O.M.I.
Principal.

COAT OF ARMS

This is our school's coat of arms. The red cross means that our school is catholic. The blue feathers stand for "Blue Quills." The tepee on the green signifies that in our school there are Indians from the prairies, while the spruce tree stand for the Indians of the forest regions.

The original of this drawing was done in France, by Mr. Jacques Pecnard, cousin of Reverend Father Principal.

At last, I have the pleasure to salute the rebirth of the "Moccasin Telegram;"...one of my most cherished desires is fulfilled. I have long felt the need of such a journal. In fact, is not a school without a journal like a child deprived of his voice? The "moccasin Telegram" will be the voice of Blue Quills. It will be a means of communication with other schools; of sharing ideas and ideals. It will be another link added to the great chain of friendship which binds all the Indian Schools together as well as with those who show any interest in their welfare.

It is the pupils' work. This, I hope, will foster interest, ambition and co-operation among the children. It may also help them to become conscious of their stand in society which is considerably different from that of fifty years ago.

I sincerely believe that great benefits can be derived from the publication of the school newspaper, therefore I wholeheartedly encourage this enterprise.

To the pupils, I wish: "Success" and to the journal..."Long Life."

May God bless both children and readers........

Father E.Bernet Rollande, O.M.I.
The Staff and Pupils of the Blue Quills Indian Res. School offer their respectful greetings and prayerful wishes to the Most Reverend Maurice Boudoux, first Pastor of the newly established diocese of St. Paul.

The Apotolic Delegate

How glad and anxious we were when we heard that we might have a chance to see Bishop Maurice Boudoux at the time of the consecration of his Excellency Bishop Bourgie. At last the day came! We were to go to the highway near our school and go by bus to St. Paul, from Edmonton. After school, it did not take us long to get there. We arrived there only half an hour after we left school. We were very excited and couldn't wait until we reached the highway. Then we lined up, ten abreast, and started off. We were holding large flags of very bright colours. It was cold, but we did not mind; we were very happy. We waited for any cars came, passed by and were lost in a cloud of dust. But finally, at last one car came. It was approaching, slowing down and stopped at us and blessed us. Then he got out and talked to us and blessed us. He was very kind and friendly.

About fifty-three cars followed him. When they all had gone out of sight, we started off again. We were very happy because we had seen the representative of the Pope in our country.

Florence Large
Grade VIII

The Bishop's Coronation

We did not see the Consecration Ceremony, but we saw the sacrifice to altar. But many of the Sisters went and they told us about it. We were very happy. They said it lasted very long but it was a nice ceremony. We are very grateful now we have a good Bishop who lives near us.

Chinese Tache
Grade IV

Benediction

On the day of the consecration of the most Rev. Maurice Boudoux, we did not have the chance to attend. However, we had the opportunity to go to Benediction. We were very happy. We were accompanied by our teacher Sister Au Toitini and our classmate Sister Marie. Our sister Irene Lefebvre went in the big truck which was driven by Willie. We went to the church, it was near eight o'clock. We jumped off the truck and walked to the church. We joined the line and we gave our places in the front. We were very happy because we knew that the sisters of our school had made some preparations for us. We waited for a while until the organ began to play. It was the first time we heard a pipe organ.

Two Fathers came in evidently to give
THE VICAR'S VISIT

The Monday following his consecration His Excellency Bishop J. Baudoux came to visit us at school. We were very glad to see him coming and we were all eager to see him again. We went to see him in his study and he went up to second floor to visit our chapel. They liked to see him very much and they asked him many questions. After the chapel evening, we rang the bell and Father Principal came out to meet him. He was very kind and I believe that he liked us. Anyway we always thought so much of him because Father Principal likes children and especially our dear Bishop.

Cherrelling Corbin
Grade V

THE NEXT DAY HOLY MASS

On the following morning the Bishop said Holy Mass. The thing that struck me during his mass, is that when he turned around to give the blessing, he did not say "Dominus Vobiscum" but he said:

"Te Vulte."

Before Holy Communion he gave us Holy Communion. He looked very kind to our pastor; he is also looking very tall and thin. He seemed very kind and I believe that he liked us. Anyway we always thought so much of him because Father Principal likes children and especially our dear Bishop.

Abraham Eagle
Grade V

TH HISTORIA

Her Father J. Heller

before we left for the summer holidays last June, we went to say good-bye to our dear old Father Heller, but we never thought that it was for the last time. He used to be such a kind father for him and that will do last time. He used to be good girls, but he was very kind to us. He died at the end of August, just before we came back from our trip. He was certainly a very kind man, a true friend to his pupils, parents and children. We who had seen him only a few months before, could hardly believe it. In him, we lost our dear old friend.

He was really devoted to the Indians as he was among them since he joined the Oblate Order in 1908 and came to Canada after his Holy Priesthood in 1909. He spent his first twelve years with the Cree Indians in Saskatchewan, then he went to work among the Ojibway Indians in Ontario. He came to Ontario to study take until 1919. In that year, he came to our parish as a missionary. He worked among the Ojibway Indians in Chapleau, Le Griff and Cold Lake. He worked in Chapleau for two years, after that he went back to Ontario to study at the Oblate Seminary in Toronto. In 1923, he came to Cold Lake where he stayed until December 26, 1944. In that year he became assistant priest and in 1945 he became parish priest. He lived here piously and quietly. He always had a kind word for everyone. He was very modest, but he was humble. The Chippewa Indians spoke his language and he knew their customs. He was very kind to everyone. He died on July 27, 1945.

The chief of the tribe chief came to Father Heller's funeral in St-Paul. He had a special place for him at Le Griff after his consecration. Although we do not see him often, we feel sure that he does not forget us either and that now that he is with God he will continue to help us in our prayers.

We hope that He will assist especially Cherrelling Lartin a grade V pupil who took his place in teaching the prayers to the Chippewa children.

Jamie Eganlie
Grade VIII
OUR NEW SUPERINTENDENT

We came back from our holidays only to find that nearly all the staff were changed. We were very disappointed when we heard that Sister Josephine had gone. We were sorry to hear that even the superior had left. We thought that she was a good teacher and we would miss her if she had not returned.

I guess all nuns are kind but we were glad to see that the new ones were just as nice. We hope they will stay here with us. The staff of teachers is complete; classes are also.

Sister Josephine was replaced by Sister Immaculate. Sister Immaculate is replaced by Sister Josephine. Sister Josephine is replaced by Sister Immaculate. The students who were taught by Sister Josephine are now taught by their teacher now. This year we have a new nun in charge of the school. She is very nice and we are glad to have her.

OUR LAST TICNIC

We did not enjoy playing "Go Fish" very much because we were all anxious to go home. We were very glad to see the boys and girls who have been so devoted to our welfare. We are very grateful for their kindness and our assistance of our prayers.

Eliza Cardinal
Grade V

Mr. Alex Goddard, the new Substitute teacher, is very kind. He is very nice because he is kind and lovely. We shall do our best to do as he likes us to do.

Eliza Cardinal

THE ROSARY

The month of October is the month of the Holy Rosary. We please the Blessed Virgin very much when we say the Rosary. She answered our prayers when we asked her to say it often. Bernadette saw her. They taught her how to say it. We love her very much. Our Mother gave us each a pair of beads and we were glad before we went to sleep every day.

Caroline Cardinal
Grade IV

"Peace and rest rise unspoken thoughts when we pray."

More than ever sought by prayer than this world dreams of.

Tennyson
EXHIBITION

No one can imagine our excitement and happiness when we heard that our school had come first at the Edmonton and Calgary Exhibition this summer.

When we came back from the holidays we all went to the sewing room to see who had the prizes. For the sewing only, we got forty first prizes and about twenty second. In all the school we received over a hundred prizes counting the school exhibits. This is a great joy for us.

We were glad for the exhibition money and we all went in the girls' room. Most of the girls got their present. Father Principal gave us the money for our prizes. On that same occasion the girls received some badges for cooking, sewing and knitting and housekeeping. They have sewed their badges on their school dresses and they are proud to wear them. We hope that many more of the girls will get some badges next year. We also hope to have many prizes at the exhibition and come first again.

Herman Cardinal
Grade V

POTATO HARVEST

In the last days of September, all the boys went to pick potatoes. We left in the morning in the wagon and came back late in the afternoon. We did not pick up many balls of potatoes because the potatoes were few. Father Principal had to go and buy some at Rhome, in the truck.

John Steinhauser
Grade II

EDITORIAL

The "Tocassin Telegram" was started by the Reverend Sister Catherine Coutelle in 1927. She was wholeheartedly devoted to its development and progress. We may well say that her work was crowned with success.

Owing to circumstances in 1942 the publication ceased. We are now attempting to bring back to life and publish the "Tocassin Telegram." It is of course the work of the pupils who are very enthusiastic about it.

For the printing of this issue we had recourse to the charity of the Reverend Sister Valletivier. She kind enough to make our copies on her Ditto. We are indeed most grateful and may she receive here our heartfelt thanks.

We hope that with the contributions of our friends and subscribers we may be able to buy a machine for the printing of the next "Tocassin Telegram."

The Editor

Broaches

Besides the girls who received badges, some have received "Broaches." They are: Catherine Roth, Elaine McFetters and Doris Pinone. These broaches were awarded for the three years of training which comprises: Cooking, Sewing, Knitting and Housekeeping. Our sincere congratulations!

Vivian

ONLY after you have seen a demonstration of this amazing new Ditto Direct Process Duplicator will you fully appreciate how much time and money have been saved in duplicating efficiency. Here is speed, simplicity and foolproof operation such as you have never seen before.

The new Ditto Model D15 Duplicator employs the famous Ditto Direct Process Duplicating Principle — there are no stencils to cut nor type or carbon to use. The Ditto original is a sheet of paper. A deposit of dye is placed on the sheet by writing, typing or drawing thru Ditto Direct Process Carbon Paper. The carbon comes in four colors — purple, red, green and blue. All colors may be used from the same original and all will reproduce in a simple operation.

This master or original, prepared in advance, is equivalent at any time to a typed or written original for instant use. Just clamp it to the cylinder of the D15 machine and run your copies — 10 inking, no make-ready — more than 100 copies per minute — 3/10 and more copies from each original. If you run only a few copies, your original may be used again and again over and over until all the dye deposit is exhausted.

The duplication of drawings in colors is amazingly simple. Just draw on a sheet of paper through Ditto Direct Process Carbon using any of the 4 colors available. Your carbon copy becomes your original or master from which the copies are made.

Whether you need copies frequently or only on occasion, you can find no simpler way to make them than on this new Ditto Model D15 Duplicator. It's ready for instant use. There's no inking — no preparation of any kind.

Anything you write, type or draw becomes instantly available for all who should have copies. The cost is so low you will always say — "Let's do it on Ditto."

Dear Father Rollande:

I have a requisition for a Ditto type mimeograph duplicator for your school.

I wish you would give this machine a thorough going over and advise us whether you like the machine. You might also advise us whether there are any faults that you can find and whether you consider it easy and clean to operate. Any other features you might care to point out will be appreciated.

I remain,

Dear Father Rollande:

I have your letter of May 28th, and am glad to hear that the duplicator is working satisfactorily and you are putting it to good use.

I have your requisition of May 23rd for more duplicator equipment, and I am arranging to send you a shading wheel, three tint plates, stencils for music, note punches, color-change pads and a transparent sheet.

I contacted the Roneo representative in the city and he advises me that a stylus plate has been sent you which can be used as a signature pad or signature plate. This representative states that photographic stencils and printographed stencils are very complicated to work with and recommends that any printographed work required should be done by people who have the proper facilities, such as a camera and a projector for this type of work.

Sir,

As the number of our pupils has much increased in the last year and as there are some applications for admission of new pupils as soon as we can receive them, I must put up new buildings for new buildings for the accommodation of our children. The School room, Dormitories have become too small and we have made plans for the erection this year of a building 60 x 30 feet with an elevation of 21 or 22 feet. This building will of course be a source of great expense and as it is for the benefit of the Indian children that we undertake it, it seems to me that I am justified in applying to the Indian Department for their help and assistance. All the materials are now ready and His Lordship Bishop Grandin has kindly lent me his best carpenter to take charge of the construction. We will have a good stone foundation made under the whole building and its addition of 15 x 20. With this information it is easy for you to figure the amount of the expenses already incurred for the lumber, stones, lime, &c., &c. I think myself that the buildings when completed will cost not very far from $4,000.00 to $6,000.00. I know that the Department has taken upon itself the greater share of the expenses in the construction of other Boarding Schools, and this knowledge makes me hope that you will be willing to help me also.

I am told that the Blue Quill's and Saddle Lake Reserve Indians are agitating just now for a Boarding School of their own. It is needless to say that most of our pupils come from Blue Quill's.
Quill's, the granting to them or to one of the other Reserves of a Boarding School would be the closing of our own. We are willing to receive all the Indian Children that the Department will provide for, and with this school for Catholic Indians, and that of Red Deer for Protestants, Indians of this Agency have not much ground for complaint.

Would it be too much to ask the Department to instruct their Agent to use his influence with his Indians in order to bring the parents of pupils to leave their children at School until we are satisfied that they know enough to be benefitted by their stay with us. This is our greatest difficulty just now. After three or four years, and even sometimes after only two years in the School, parents must take their children away, to have their help in their work. Good advice from the Agent or Instructor at such time would induce some of the parents, if not all, to leave their children with us and it would be a great help to us.

I am anxious to know your answer to the Indians' petition, because I want to start work on our new building as soon as possible. If you wish, I will send you a copy of the plan I showed to Mr. Agent Sibbald when he came to visit our School.

Hoping to receive a favourable answer to my request for assistance, I remain,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Sgd. H. Grandin.

Saddle Lake, 1st July, 1897.

Sir,

For the last two days I have been busy looking around this reserve for a good site for our Boarding School. After visiting with the Reverend Fathers Boulenc and Therien all the places that were likely to suit us, we have come to the conclusion that the best situation of all would be the location of our Mission on Blue Quill's reserve. The only drawback is the scarcity of water. You told us when we met you at St. Albert that you were to send soon some kind of a drill or boring machine to Onion Lake, and that we might have the use of it after they were done with it at that point. Could you not invert the order of things and send the drill here as soon as possible to enable us to see if we can find water on our present station. We can hardly begin our building without being sure of a good supply of water, and as we are ready to begin our school house at once, you will understand how much we wish to have the use of your machinery as early as it can be brought here.

In the hope that you will grant our petition,

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

sgd. H. Grandin.

The amount of costs for work performed is larger than the amount of costs for materials. The reason for this seemingly anomaly is because all the doors, window-frames, windows, &c. have been made by the Contractor himself and the other Carpenters employed by him, instead of having been supplied ready made from Edmonton or Calgary.

The nearest points to have all the lumber required were Edmonton and Lac la Biche, both places being about ninety miles distant from Saddle Lake.

The price of hauling from both places was eight dollars ($8.00) per thousand feet B.M. The average price of lumber used in the buildings, bought either at Edmonton or at Lac la Biche, has been sixteen dollars ($16.00) per thousand feet B.M., which with the price of hauling added, brings up the price of lumber delivered at Saddle Lake to twenty four dollars, ($24.00) per thousand feet B.M.

On the 1st of August last, date upon which the above accounts are closed, the buildings were sufficiently advanced to operate the removal from Lac la Biche, but a great deal of indispensable work was still remaining undone in the inside, such as ceilings, partitions, &c.

Since the 1st of August, the same four workmen, i.e. P. Bowes, Contractor, A. Nemoz, B. Orillon and O. Vermette, carpenters, were busy finishing the buildings and will not likely get through before the end of the month.

We, moreover, want without delay and at whatever cost, a system to pump water and force it in the establishment. Pending this water has to be carted from the Saskatchewan, nearly two miles away, at great cost.

At the end of the month there will consequently be an additional expenditure of about $1,000.00, which we will have met. The Department, when you have communicated this information, will I am sure, consider all these circumstances, as you yourself will do, when preparing the next Estimates.
I hereby declare to the best of my belief that the quantities of material mentioned in this Statement have been used in the erection of the Roman Catholic Boarding School, that the values placed thereon and on the labour, are fair and just.

Edmonton, 4th September, 1895.

My dear Mr Forget,

The Statements attached were handed over to me yesterday evening by Mr Sibbald himself, Indian Agent at Saddle Lake.

He said that not being notified by the Department to meddle in any way with the buildings of the Boarding School removed from Lac la Biche to my Agency, I do not think I have anything to do with them. Nevertheless having seen what has been done, I am ready to sign the attached declaration, written in my own hand before leaving the Reserve to come here yesterday. I willingly will sign said declaration, if Mr Forget thinks I ought to.

If therefore the testimony of the Agent is necessary, he is ready to sign the declaration.

Yours,

Sgd. H. Leduc, O.M.I.

Pt.

A.R. Forget, Esq.
Indian Commissioner,
Winnipeg.
Edmonton, 4th September, 1898

My dear Mr Forget,

I am forwarding today a detailed statement of expenditure incurred by the Roman Catholic Mission upon buildings erected for the Blue Quill's Boarding School.

You know under what condition and circumstances the Lac la Biche Indian Industrial School was removed to Saddle Lake. This too place at the request of the Indians, with your approbation and the incentive of the Indian Department.

We operated the removal and paid all expenses in this connection being sure that we would be recouped by the Government in good time for this institution no longer out of a reserve but immediately on Blue Quill's and for the use of the Indians only.

I therefore beg to ask you in the name of His Lordship Bishop Grandin and also in that of His Lordship Bishop Legal to be good enough to include in your Estimates, and recommend the reimbursement of our expenses aggregating from 31st July, 1897 to 1st of August, 1898, to the sum of $5,650.86.

Yours,

sgd. H. Leduc, O.M.I. Pt.

Remarks:

The amount of costs for work performed is larger than the amount of costs for materials. The reason of this seemingly anomaly is because all the doors, windows, window-frames, etc., have been made by the contractor himself and the other carpenters employed by him, instead of having been supplied ready-made from Edmonton or Calgary.

The nearest points to have all the lumber required, were Edmonton and Lac la Biche, both places being about ninety miles distant from Saddle Lake.

The price of hauling from both places was eight dollars $8.00, per thousand feet R.M. The average price of lumber used in the buildings, bought either at Edmonton or at Lac la Biche has been sixteen dollars, $16.00 per thousand feet R.M., which with the price of hauling added, brings up the price of lumber delivered at Saddle Lake to twenty-four dollars, $24.00 per thousand ft. Referring to your letter of the 15th September last, I beg to state that His Lordship Bishop Legal was advised of the amounts appropriated for Roman Catholic Schools in his Diocese, and the Bishop now requests that the sum of $2500.00 voted to aid in removal of Lac la Biche School buildings, to Blue Quill's Reserve, Saddle Lake Agency, be paid over to him.
